column2: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 20 Almost unnoticed in the final weeks of last year, the General Assembly overwhelmingly adopted a resolution proclaiming "The Inadmissability of the Policy of Hegemonism in International Relations."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) A Circuit Court judge will hear a suit Thursday in which a marketing company is demanding $237,000 in payments from Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who is seeking the Presidential nomination.

Participants in the fixed-income markets generally believe there is little to cheer about these days, thanks to a mix of expectations of high inflation, depressing developments both domestically and overseas and the onset of a year of heavy new financing activity.

MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP, N.J. Several times each month cars bearing diplomatic license plates roll into a secluded section of the township near the Earle Naval Ammunition Depot. There, the men in the cars break out compact submachine guns and handguns, take up positions and begin firing at simulated "enemy" positions.

The oil lobby on Capitol Hill usually works smoothly and speaks with a single voice. Not in the last few days. First, the major oil companies fell to arguing vehemently, and publicly, with independent producers. Then the independents started scrapping among themselves. Small wonder. There is something like $50 billion in tax benefits at stake. But there is a larger question at stake than who gets how much, and it is being ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 About 50 leaders from various anti-abortion organizations met in Washington for a three-day conference that started Saturday, to plan this year's agenda of political activism and prepare for Tuesday's scheduled March for Life on the Capitol.
A short while back I offered an opinion on how to tell whether an eggplant has few or many seeds. It was my educated guess that the younger the eggplant, the fewer the seeds.

A new study sponsored by Ralph Nader and conducted by college students challenges the widely held view that academic tests closely predict academic performance. The authors of the 555-page report conclude that multiple-choice examinations, like the Scholastic Aptitude Tests taken by millions each year, do not, in fact, predict much of anything.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Presidential candidates of both parties have invested more than $2.8 million in the Iowa caucuses, at least 10 times as much as the nation's earliest delegate selection process attracted only four years ago.

PASADENA, CALIF. WHEN the third quarter ended Sunday in Super Bowl XIV, the Los Angeles Rams were leading the Pittsburgh Steelers, 19-17, and as the offensive unit moved to the other end of the field, Fred Dryer stood on the sideline and surveyed the situation.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 20 (AP) Mayor John Rousakis of Savannah was arrested and charged with drunken driving early today, the police said.

America's grain weapon is likely to hit its target: The loss of 17 million tons of American corn and wheat is sure to disrupt Soviet plans to expand livestock herds and may force the depletion of that country's limited grain reserves.
THE walk-up apartment building may not be the most glamorous investment in town, but it is certainly a good one for investors seeking longterm capital gains.

FRANCOIS PERRIN (Patrick Dewaere) is a child of misfortune. He suspects that when he was a baby and in a public nurs ery, he was given to the wrong parent. "There is every possibility," he says, "that I am not me." Now he works in a mill factory and is retained mostly because he's an excellent soccer player, though he's too hot-headed and independent to play on the factory's firststring team.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The 96th Congress, which is to reconvene on Tuesday, is expected to be dominated by foreign policy and military issues in the aftermath of the Soviet incursion into Afghanistan and the continuing crisis in Iran.

ONE of the most enjoyable elements of regular dancegoing is the chance to see a variety of interpretations of the same role. On Saturday afternoon, Dance Theater of Harlem, in the next to last week of its winter season at City Center, presented some changes from the first-night casts of its new productions of "Swan Lake" and "Paquita."
ATLANTA, Jan. 20 Scott Hamilton heard the loud applause and shivered. Then Scott Cramer's marks were announced over the public address system.
No matter where life takes them, there are those for whom New York is always home.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Defense Department has decided to give the Army a green light for full-scale production of the sophisticated but controversial XM-1 main battle tank as part of an advance in the Army's weaponry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 President Carter proposed today that the Moscow Olympics be moved to another country or postponed or canceled if the Soviet Union failed to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan within a month.

MISSISSAUGA, Ontario, Jan. 19--Police officers in this Toronto suburb are investigating a criminal ring selling stolen American identity papers to immigrants seeking illegal entry into the United States.

PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil As Dr. Paulo Ernani Evangelista's 7-year-old son sat in front of the television, an advertisement flashed on the screen showing a handsome man lighting a cigarette, kindling a world of material and sexual success. The youngster stuck a pencil in his mouth, turned to his father and said, "Dad, why don't you smoke?"

DALLAS, Jan. 20 Dallas voters, in an election that had been delayed for almost 10 months by the United States Justice Department, yesterday assured the election of three minority group members to the City Council.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Somebody recently sent Representative John B. Anderson a book called "Conquering Loneliness" and that title sums up Mr. Anderson's problem as he pursues his longshot run for the Republican Presidential nomination.

TOKYO, Jan. 20 The Nissan Motor Company, in a move that demonstrates the growing international strength of the Japanese auto industry, has decided to start production of trucks and later passenger cars in Europe in a joint venture with the Spanish Government, the company said this weekend.

ST. DENIS, Reunion, Jan. 20 (AP) A tropical storm that lashed this tropical island over the weekend killed at least four people, injured about 12 and drove 500 from their homes, officials reported today. They said about 300 houses were inundated or covered with mud by the storm, which struck the island late Friday and early yesterday. Reunion, a French overseas territory, is 570 miles east of Madagascar.

PASADENA, CALIF. THE hometown fans of the Los Angeles Rams didn't boo their team Sunday in the Super Bowl. Just a month ago, when the Rams ended their regular season with a 29-14 loss to New Orleans Saints, fans booed the team during and after the game; it was not the first time they had done so during a 9-7 season, and their response provoked a bitter enuciation of the fans by several Rams players.
BONN, Jan. 20 After months of American prodding, the West German Government is now considering, in response to the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, an increase in its 1980 defense budget.
Boxing suffered its fourth fatality in less than two months when Harlan Hoosier, a 13-year-old from Beauty, Ky., died of brain contusions last Friday in Huntington, W. Va.

Old Dominion has an identity crisis. Since joining the major college bas ketball ranks for the 1977 season, the Monarchs have been fighting for recognition. Although Old Dominion reached the quarterfinal round of the National Invitation Tournament with an upset of Clemson last season, the women's team, led by Nancy Lieberman, which won the national title, was more publicized.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Carter Administration is trying to improve relations with Turkey and strengthen that country's military forces.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 20 (AP) Venezuela has called home its Ambassador to Cuba because policemen fired on two groups of Cubans seeking asylum in embassies in Havana, the Venezuelan Foreign Minister, Jose Alberto Zambrano, said here yesterday.
BADGASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 20 (AP) Marie-Theres Nadig of Switzerland won her sixth downhill of the World Cup season today by beating Annemarie Proell Moser of Austria by three-tenths of a second.

Dr. Niki Ellen Kantrowitz and Dr. Ira Steven Goldman, senior residents in internal medicine at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, were married yesterday at the Carlyle. Rabbi Elliot Spar officiated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Carter Administration has informed Egypt that it will ask Congress to approve an additional $1.1 billion in military credits over the next two years to allow Egypt to buy F-16 fighter planes and other sophisticated American military equipment, officials said today.

NBC-TV officials said yesterday that President Carter's remarks about a possible United States boycott of the Moscow Olympics did not affect, for now, their plans to provide television coverage of next summer's Games.

THAT small but discerning audience that never misses televi sion showings of films like "Women Behind Bars" and "Girls' Reformatory," not to mention works like "Gestapo Vixens" that are usually exhibited on 42d Street, may derive a mild degree of stimulation from "Prisoner: Cell Block H."

The New York Region Econometric Model developed by the Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates of Philadelphia is a computer program that uses 1,500 equations and 1,400 variables to define the interaction of the economy of the metropolitan area and its relationship to the rest of the nation.

MONTEBELLO, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP) Cesar Chavez, leader of the United Farm Workers, has announced a boycott of the Lucky Stores supermarkets. At a demonstration at one of the markets yesterday, the first anniversary of the union's strike against California and Arizona lettuce ...

Helena M. Naimark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham D. Naimark of Rego Park, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Edward J. Sachar, chairman of the department of psychiatry at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Abram L. Sachar of Newtonville, Mass.

A State Supreme Court justice has held that New York City bears a share of the liability for damages which could total millions of dollars in the 1973 collapse of the former Broadway Central Hotel. Four persons were killed in the collapse, and about 40 people were injured.

TOWSON, Md., Jan. 20 (UPI) Harold Solomon averted three set points in the first set tiebreaker today and rallied for a 7-6, 6-0 victory over Tim Gullikson in the final of the $75,000 Baltimore Grand Prix tennis tournament.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 Senator Edward M. Kennedy finished first today as he and President Carter ambushed Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. in a straw poll of delegates to the platform convention of the California Democratic State Central Committee.

The indictment of a prominent Manhattan businesswoman on charges of stealing more than $10 million in Federal and other funds earmarked for the launching of women's businesses has focused attention on the rising rate of nonviolent crime among women.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 Prosecutors in the Federal income tax fraud trial of Attorney General William J. Scott of Illinois provided new details last week of what they have described as Mr. Scott's "secret life" of illicitly financed travel.

THE BIG GALLERY Sheila Doyle-Stevens, a British painter, was studying at Columbia University's School of Arts in 1975 when she formed the Claremont Arts Group, whose members came from Europe as well as the United States. The group has held three exhibitions at the Cork Gallery in Avery Fisher Hall, at Lincoln Center.

PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 20 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Huang Hua of China told refugees from Afghanistan today that Peking was on their side and would do everything it could to relieve their suffering.

PETER SCHUMANN'S Bread and Puppet Theater celebrates the underdog, the outcast and the rebel in society. Its new play, "Ah! or the First Washerwoman Cantata," now running as a Dodger Theater presentation at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, takes an heroic view of a homely subject. By "washerwoman," Mr. Schumann means not just servants but all women who are devoted to domestic chores.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 20 (AP) Five sections of crowded wooden bleachers atop the grandstand at the bullring in Sincelejo collapsed today, and hospital officials said at least 147 persons were killed and about 500 were injured.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 20 Trailing with less than 13 minutes to play in a football game they were expected to win convincingly, the Pittsburgh Steelers, victims of interceptions the last two times they had the ball, began the series that would win their fourth championship very unimpressively.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 20 (Reuters) Venezuela said that it had cut by 15 percent the amount of oil it sells directly to the big multinational oil companies.

Ilene P. Karpf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Karpf of Syosset, L.I., and Michael J. Hassett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Hassett Jr. of Pittsburgh, were married yesterday at the Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, L.I. Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg of Congregation Daat Elohim in New York performed the ceremony.

"THE Sounds From the Mountains," a Japanese family drama from the director Mikio Naruse, has a precision and intimacy that makes it reminiscent of Yasujiro Ozu's works dating from this same period, the middle 1950's.

PHOEBE NEVILLE choreographs dreams. All four works offered by the Phoebe Neville Dance Company Thursday night at the Washington Square United Methodist Church were as unsettling as those vivid dreams that one can recall but not explain.
CHARLESTON, S.C. (AP) The world premiere of Arthur Miller's "The American Clock" will be presented at the 1980 Spoleto U.S.A. arts festival.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 20 (AP) A Haitian woman whose body washed ashore died after being shoved into the ocean by smugglers, the Hollywood police say.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 20 (UPI) Brian Winters hit a jump shot from just inside the 3-point circle with four seconds remaining today to give the Milwaukee Bucks an 89-88 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

TOKYO, Jan. 20 (AP) The Toyota Motor Sales Company, the sales arm of the Toyota Motor Company, said that the company produced a record 2.99 million vehicles in 1979. This was 4.9 percent higher than the 2.85 million Toyota cars, trucks and buses produced in 1978, officials said.

DES MOINES, Jan. 20 "The fact is, we can both afford to lose," said Tim Kraft, President Carter's campaign manager, in an unaccustomed moment of thoughtful relaxation from the intensity of the Carter-Kennedy campaign here.

SAN ONOFRE, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI) About 1,800 workers were scheduled to return to work at the San Onofre nuclear plant tomorrow after a two-day wildcat strike. Officials of the Plumbers and Piepfitters Union Local 230 said the employees would resume work on two new nuclear generating units. The strike began after the dismissal of 13 pipefitters who walked off their jobs in a dispute over working conditions on the project.

DUSSELDORF, West Germany This city's trash can is 10 stories tall, about a block long and sits in an industrial quarter amid power plants and oil tanks. But it does more than merely contain garbage: It transforms it into energy.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 20 Not long after Ray Malavasi succeeded George Allen as the coach of the Los Angeles Rams in 1978, he proclaimed, "Owners want their teams in the Super Bowl, and that's what we're going to accomplish."
EAST BERLIN, Jan. 20 When the East German leader, Erich Honecker, held his traditional New Year reception for diplomats, he singled out Gunter Gaus, the West German envoy, for special attention.

LONDON, Jan. 20 With the Marsh McLennan Companies considering whether to go ahead with a hostile bid for the C.T. Bowring Company, Bowring executives may be musing about how disloyalty was punished in centuries past.
BOSTON, Jan. 20 (AP) Gus Williams scored 12 of his game-high 29 points after regulation time to help the Seattle SuperSonics to a 108-106 doubleovertime victory over the Boston Celtics today.

THE flute is a very popular instrument these days, not only with regular concertgoers but with contemporary composers as well. Barbara Held, a flutist from Minnesota who has been living in Barcelona since 1973, specializes in the performance of new flute music, and she devoted herself to this task in Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday afternoon.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music, on the eve of its new repertory season, is rejoicing in five plays, 10,000 subscribers, a company of 33 actors and what Harvey Lichtenstein, its president, calls "a fund-raising drive that is murder on wheels."
WASHINGTON DECLINING petroleum demand is giving President Carter some leeway in framing 1980 con servation policies that are expected to be announced in the coming economic messages.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) The Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's largest commodity futures exchange, has taken a step toward entering the energy field.
Figures for tournament attendance in the 70's make it clear that the number of participants in competitive bridge activities has increased slightly.

Terry Bradshaw was the player who made the difference in yesterday's Super Bowl, in the opinion of two coaches whose teams came close but not close enough to the National Football League's championship game.

The New York Rangers are beginning to talk about themselves as if they were troubled adolescents. After last night's 2-1 loss to the Chicago Black Hawks, Eddie Johnstone suggested that the team was "going through a stage."

Seven Chinese scientists, all of them men and women in their 40's in white laboratory coats, settled around a table at Rockefeller University with their language textbooks, eager for another lesson in shaping the unfamiliar English words into simple sentences.
IT is extraordinary that generations of literate waterfowlers have failed to chronicle ways for dealing with duck-blind tedium, perhaps the greatest challenge the sport offers.
Q. Mr. President, assuming the Soviets do not pull out of Afghanistan any time soon, do you favor the U.S. participating in the Moscow Olympics, and if not, what are the alternatives?

PRIVATE lives, private agonies have become public affairs on television and the questions are raised: Is this needed? Is this helpful? A generalized answer can never meet the specific question. In the case of "Joan Robinson: One Woman's Story," the specific answer is strongly affirmative on both counts.

WASHINGTON At a Peking banquet in 1972, Premier Zhou Enlai lifted a delicious morsel off his plate and placed it carefully with his chop sticks on the plate of Richard Nixon. The American President, who had been briefed on this custom by which a host honors a guest, responded correctly with a nod of thanks.

A heavy financing calendar, including an assortment of top-rated names, faces the fixed-income markets this week. However, no single issue is as big as last Tuesday's sale of $450 million in debentures for the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company.

HONG KONG, Monday, Jan. 21 (AP) Gold opened this morning on the Hong Kong market at $822.61 a troy ounce, down $1.06 from Saturday's close. Dealers said the precious metal dropped to $820.89 in initial trading.
WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 20 Bojan Krijaz, a 23-year-old Yugoslav who has been close to his first World Cup skiing victory all season, finally achieved it today in the slalom.

PHOENIX, Jan. 20 Jeff Mitchell thought he would be nervous on the threshold of his first victory on the PGA Tour, but he was not. He could tell because his hands were not shaking on the putts, even when he rammed home a 15-foot birdie putt on the 18th green today to add yet another stroke to his three-shot lead.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 20 (Reuters) Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, faced by a presidential election boycott in Iran's ethnic border regions, today made a gesture of conciliation toward the Sunni Moslem populations.

LONDON, Jan. 20 (Reuters) The Marathon Oil Company said that its subsidiary, Marathon Oil U.K. Ltd., had encountered significant hydrocarbon shows in Block 16-3a in the North Sea. It said the well's production potential could not be determined at this point.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI) Jack Ham, a Pittsburgh Steeler all-pro linebacker who suffered an ankle injury in the next-to-last game of the regular season, says it was tougher to watch a Super Bowl game than to play in it.

Dr. Ronni Lee Seltzer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Seltzer of Roslyn Heights, L.I., and Gary H. Broder, son of Doris Broder of Brooklyn and the late Leonard Broder, were married yesterday. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at the Pierre.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20--President Tito's left leg was amputated at noon today to avoid a spread of gangrene that jeopardized his life, his doctors announced.

DETROIT, Jan. 20 (AP) The Ford Motor Company plans to close seven car and truck assembly plants this week because of a strike at a major supplier. Five of the plants are in the United States and two are in Canada.

Dr. Leslie Z. Taynor, a periodontist, and Dr. Arthur G. Mones, a clinical psychologist, both of Roslyn, L.I., were married yesterday in New York. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony at the Tower Suite.
PLATO, I believe, would not have understood this book. He might have imagined the baths on which Edmund White reports in his Baedeker, but the leather bars, the bike boys, disco group-grope, ...
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 20 (AP) Playing nearly flawless tennis, Martina Navratilova defeated Greer Stevens, 6-0, 6-2, in 50 minutes and won the $24,000 first prize in a $125,000 Avon tournament.

Jean Alice Rosaler and Richard Paul Schram, both of San Francisco, were married yesterday in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Fred J. Margulies, assisted by Rabbi Lyle Fishman, performed the ceremony in the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 16 "What can you do from the pulpit?" the preacher asked a roomful of his colleagues. "You can register people to vote. You can explain the issues to them. And you can endorse candidates, right there in church on Sunday morning."

THE American artist Anne Ryan (1889-1954) is believed to have produced some 400 or more collages in the last years of her life. It was a creative feat that astonishes us still. These collages are clearly the work of a mature artist in complete command of her medium.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 20 (UPI) The Jersey Central Power and Light Company will ask the state tomorrow to approve a rate increase that would raise residential customers' electricity bills 19 percent.

Judith Sharon Miller, daughter of Rabbi Israel Miller, senior vice president of Yeshiva University, and Mrs. Miller of New York, was married yesterday to Jay Alan Kalish, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Kalish of Far Rockaway, Queens.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 David Costello of Old Town, Me., is a 19-year-old University of Maine sophomore who works in local politics and hopes to make a career of it. The other night his telephone rang, and there was Rosalynn Carter on the line.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 At 5 P.M. yesterday afternoon there was only one undefeated major college basketball team remaining in the nation because Syracuse had just suffered its first loss. At mid-afternoon today, it appeared that De Paul would make it none.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) Following is the text of President Carter's letter to Robert J. Kane, president of the United States Olympic Committee:

Officials of the United States Olympic Committee said yesterday that they interpreted President Carter's proposal that the Olympic Games be transferred from the Soviet Union as an indication that the United States would go through the "proper channels" in such an effort. The officials said that they would therefore try to enlist the support of other nations to move the Games.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) Gov. James R. Thompson says he will approve no more advances in state aid to the financially strapped Chicago school system until the city, local banks and labor unions keep their promises to also help out.

EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 20 A special election on Tuesday to fill the seat in Congress vacated by Abner J. Mikva will be the first of the new year, and with rapidly rising prices a concern in this affluent area, economic issues have been in the forefront of the campaign.
Wondering what footwear could possibly do justice to that Russian crown sable you just sold the boat and car and mortgaged the house to buy?

WIJK AAN ZEE, the Netherlands, Jan. 17 A brilliant upset victory in the second round by Yasser Seirawan of Seattle, the 19-year-old junior world champion, over Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, the former world championship challenger, is the talk of the 42d Hoogoven International Tournament here.

DES MOINES, Jan. 20 Senator Edward M. Kennedy, charging President Carter with a major foreign policy failure in dealing with the Soviet Union, suggested today that Mr. Carter's reversal of policy over a Soviet combat brigade in Cuba last fall may have influenced Moscow's decision to intervene in Afghanistan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Two weeks after President Carter placed a partial embargo on grain sales to the Soviet Union, the program to ease the impact on farmers remains mired in technical difficulties and threatens both to place a drain on the Federal Treasury and to raise food prices for consumers, according to Administration and private experts.
A housing crush has taken hold in Manhattan, bringing with it not only disgruntlement among apartment seekers but also changes in the city's neighborhoods and in the very way New Yorkers live.
ANNISTON, Ala. The New South is over. It ended about four years ago.

PLAINVIEW, Tex., Jan. 17 In their house on the desolate plains of the Texas Panhandle on that fatal Halloween night, Loy and Louise Stone were said to be quietly bringing in the new year as it is observed by the Church of Wicca. As "flamen" and "flamenca," or keepers of the flame, for one of Wicca's branches, the Stones practiced witchcraft or said they did.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 20 (AP) Four people were killed in new terrorist attacks in Turkey, the police said today. In the southern city of Dortyol, two pedestrians on a main street were shot and killed by gunmen.

Do the record prices being paid for gold and silver reflect economic panic? Are $820 gold and $46 silver undermining the dollar and other currencies, spurring inflation and causing a flight from commodities in general?

PASADENA, CALIF. TERRY BRADSHAW seemed to have a tennis ball in his cheek, yet he kept stuffing more eating tobacco into the bulge. "My Christian brethren," said the bornagain Christian, "don't like my chewing tobacco."

Laurel Andrea Braterman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Braterman of North Miami Beach, Fla., was married at noon yesterday in Miami Lakes, Fla., to George Metzger Matis, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob D. Matis of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's brother-in-law and sister, Dr. and Mrs. Louis Pease.

WASHINGTON A recent regulatory proposal to allow savings institutions to renegotiate mortgage rates with borrowers every three to five years would substantially alter the nation's structure of mortgage lending, according to Government and industry analysts.
RICH SQUARE, N.C., Jan. 20 Ever since an enormous flock of blackbirds decided to roost in a pine thicket, this sleepy, rural town has been on the losing side of a battle with nature.

GIJON, Spain, Jan. 20 (AP) Miners today recovered the bodies of two of the four coal miners trapped in a cave-in at a pit in this northern Spanish city, the police said. Rescue teams continued digging in search of the other two miners, but held little hope they would be found alive. The miners were trapped last Thursday.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 20 They had to battle off the ropes in the fourth quarter to do it again, but the winners and still undefeated champions of Super Bowls are the Pittsburgh Steelers.
Word has been sent to Bogota and Rabat. Negotiations are under way with Uganda and South Korea. Columbia University is not pleased; neither is New York University.
RYE, N.Y., Jan. 20 Sharif Khan, top seeded in the $1,500 Apawamis Club invitation squash racquets tournament, defeated his fourth-seeded brother, Aziz, 14-18, 15-10, 18-16, 15-14, in the final today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) The Rev. Harold W. Rigney, an American missionary who spent four years in a Chinese prison during the mid-1950's, was eulogized yesterday as a man who devoted his life to service.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 14 After the assassination of numerous opposition figures here last year, many Guatemalan labor and political leaders have chosen to go into hiding and seek closer ties with the country's leftist guerrillas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) After President Carter's announcement today about boycotting the Olympics in Moscow unless Soviet troops left Afghanistan, his press secretary, Jody Powell, read to reporters the following excerpt from the 1980 handbook for Soviet Communist Party activists:

MAHWAH, N.J., Jan. 20 (AP) The police switchboard in this northern Bergen County community was flooded with calls this afternoon when about 700 customers of Orange and Rockland Utilities Company lost their electricity, threatening their chances of watching the Super Bowl.

Shirley Verrett, Ashley Putnam and other singers will take part in a second subscription series of vocal chamber music, to be given starting in March by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. Like the first series, last year, the three midweek evening concerts will explore unusual repertory in which solo voices combine with instruments.

MONTSERRAT CABALLE offered what she called her "silver jubilee" recital at Carnegie Hall last night, meaning her 25th New York recital since her debut in the same hall in 1965. It was a pretty typical Caballe affair, full of capricious changes, musical mannerisms and gorgeous singing.

The father of a 19-year-old patient at Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in Brentwood, L.I., has charged that his son was beaten Friday while in a straitjacket. Suffolk County police were investigating the charge yesterday.

New York City will lose about 97,000 jobs in 1980, 3.5 percent of its total, in a recession that will start early this year and will hit the city and its surrounding regions harder than it will the nation as a whole, according to a new economic projection.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20 The Moscow publication Sovetsky Sport said today that the Soviet Union would send athletes to Lake Placid, N.Y., for the Winter Olympics no matter what Washington did about the Summer Olympics in Moscow.

Expenditures of $13,790 million are recommended for the 1980-81 fiscal year, an increase of $683 million, or 5.2 percent, from the 1979-80 level. This increase is approximately one half the predicted increase in the rate of inflation during the next year.
IN the course of a flight across the United States, an airplane is tracked by dozens of radars and six or seven control centers. Consider an airliner flying from New York to Los Angeles.

DETROIT, Jan. 21 The old order changeth this year at the General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest auto maker and the very model of the modern industrial corporation. Both Thomas A. Murphy, the company's chairman, and Elliott M. Estes, its ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 In the State of the Union message sent to Congress today, President Carter said he was limiting his "major new" domestic proposals to these "critical few":
OTTAWA, Jan. 21 The Canadian Government today anounced the expulsion of three Soviet Embassy personnel on charges of having engaged in espionage activities against the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 President Carter, outlining a modest package of legislative proposals for the election-year Congress, formally announced today that his budget for the fiscal year 1981 would seek no tax cuts.
Prices broke sharply in the fixed-income market yesterday to provide an assortment of record yields in toprated securities.
David Maxwell and Edward Bona combined to score 35 points and lead Fordham to a 91-79 victory over Marist College last night at the Rams' Rose Hill gymnasium in the Bronx.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 Calling for tight new limits on government spending at the state and local level, Governor Carey proposed today a $13.79 billion budget for New York State for fiscal 1980-81.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) The Justice Department sued two trade associations today, alleging that they conspired to fix brokerage commission rates in the United States for foreignexchange transactions between banks.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 21 (AP) Kenny Reynolds stole the ball three times in a three-minute span early in the second half to ignite a South Carolina surge and spark the Gamecocks to an 88-49 triumph over Dartmouth tonight.
DETROIT, Jan. 21 (AP) The Ford Motor Company said today that it had formed a truck-operations division to handle the design, manufacture and sale of medium-and heavy-duty trucks in North America.

Some quick aid to Pakistan may now be, as President Carter told Congress yesterday, the "first order of business." But the understandable desire to discourage further Soviet advance in Asia runs the risk of solving one credibility problem by creating another.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 21 Several prominent liberal Democrats who in the past have backed candidates such as Senators George McGovern and Eugene J. McCarthy pledged financial aid last night to Representative John B. Anderson, the Republican Presidential candidate.
The shortage of traditional apartments in Manhattan has given rise to some unconventional options in the housing market.

GEORGE BALANCHINE'S oneact version of "Swan Lake" for the New York City Ballet is hardly everyone's idea of "Swan Lake." It is Mr. Balanchine's commentary upon the standard second act of the full-length classic, and inevitably it has the pure-dance tone of his own contemporary works.

SANTA CRUZ DE TENE-RIFE, Canary Islands, Jan. 21 (AP) Santiago Gonzalez Monzon, a 22-year-old Spanish lightweight, was in a coma today after suffering a brutal beating here Saturday night in a bout against a countryman, Jose Garcia Requena.

Railroads continue to report good earnings for the fourth quarter and for all of 1979, when freight traffic reached a record-breaking 902 billion ton miles. Yesterday, Burlington Northern Inc. and the Norfolk Western Railway reported strong results.

Using such terms as "cynical" and "insidious" in describing Mayor Koch's proposal to cut $111 million from the 1980-81 school budget, community school boards and educational organizations yesterday applauded School Chancellor Frank J. The Independent Taxi Owners Council offered a $1,000 reward yesterday for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the slayer of Louis Reyes, a taxi driver. Mr. Reyes, 25 years old, was found shot to death in his cab at 122d Street and Madison Avenue last weekend.

The Chrysler Corporation, in an effort to increase sagging sales, has announced an innovative marketing program that includes a 30-day or 1,000mile money-back guarantee and payments of $50 to people who test-drive its cars, as long as they buy some brand of car.

Patricia Koppmann, the South Dakota housewife who last year filed a lawsuit against her state Blue Shield organization after it refused to pay her surgical claims for breast reconstruction after cancer surgery, said yesterday that the company had changed its policy and that all of her claims had been paid.

Prominent feminists and the leaders of various women's groups reacted cautiously yesterday to the prospect that women might be required to register for the draft. Most opposed the idea of draft registration for either men or women but added that in the event of registration, women should not be exempted.

WHAT are the economic implications of President Carter's State of the Union Address, which stressed his planned responses to the challenges of growing Soviet military power, the Western world's overwhelming dependence on Middle Eastern oil and unrest in the developing world, exemplified by the revolution in Iran?

SYRACUSE, Jan. 24--Practice was almost over when the blondhaired boy carrying a camera as big as his head got to the gym. As the members of the Syracuse University basketball team drifted toward the locker room, he bounced over to the tallest of them and, addressing the kneecaps in front of him, said: "Roosevelt, I wanna take your picture. Would you slam-dunk one for me?"

Gerald and Miriam Fine of Port Washington, L.I., recently sent a contribution of $50 and wrote: "When our daughter was born, we decided to donate to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund instead of listing the announcement in the paper. This year is her 20th birthday, and we consider ourselves very fortunate never to have missed a year."

SIDON, Lebanon, Jan. 24 (Reuters)-- Armed assailants tried to break into an army barracks here last night and a gun battle went on for an hour, military sources said today. Several persons were wounded before the attackers were driven off.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--A bipartisan group of senators proposed legislation today that would tend to encourage more covert operations overseas by United States intelligence agencies and would reduce the Congressional and public scrutiny to which they are now subject.
Governor Carey said yesterday that he supported legislation that would set specific prison sentences for defendants convicted of felonies in New York State.

Robert Burns came into this world on Jan. 25, 1759. What better cause for a celebration? Tomorrow and Sunday at 7:30 P.M., the 221st birthday of the Scottish poet will be celebrated in style at the Community Church at 40 East 35th Street.

The Laurentian String Quartet, the resident quartet at Sarah Lawrence College, will perform Tchaikovsky's First Quartet, Wolf's "Italian Serenade," and the "Hunt" Quartet by Mozart on Sunday at 8 P.M. in the college's Reisinger Auditorium on Glen Washington Road in Bronxville, N.Y. Admission is $3 ($1.50 for student and the elderly). Information: (914) 3370700.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--A report to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission on the accident at the Three Mile Island reactor concluded today that the commission as currently organized was incapable of managing a nuclear safety program "adequate to ensure the public health and safety."

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 24--Workers have begun correcting flaws in the new $16.5 million Olympic fieldhouse, built for the 1980 winter games opening here Feb. 12, so it can meet New York State and industry safety standards.

Prominent awards for children's literature have gone to Joan W. Blos, author of "A Gathering of Days, A New England Girl's Journal, 1830-32," who has won the 1980 John Newbery Medal, and to Barbara Cooney, illustrator of "Ox-Cart Man," who has won the 1980 Randolph Caldecott Medal.

HARTFORD, Jan. 24--A state regulatory agency today ordered the Times Mirror Company, based in Los Angeles, to divest itself of The Hartford Courant or its ownership of cable television systems in Hartford and Meriden by April 1, 1981.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 24 (UPI)--Former Gov. Alf Landon, 92 years old, was in stable condition today suffering from a suspected inner ear problem at a local hospital. The 1936 Republican Presidential candidate was taken to the hospital yesterday morning after complaining of dizziness.

Confronted with a possible American boycott of the Olympic Games in Moscow next summer, the sole United States travel agency for trips to the Games went to Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday to prevent more than 10,700 Americans from possibly losing nearly half of the $15 million they had already paid for fares and accommodations.
THOMAS SCHMIDT, who made his New York debut in 1970 and teaches at Concordia College, returned for his second major piano recital Wednesday night, this time at Alice Tully Hall.

President Carter's statement that the United States would use any means, including military force, to repel an attack on the Persian Gulf accentuates but does nothing to improve the American strate gic situation in that region.

KING VIDOR, one of the handful of American film directors who can without the anticipation of argument be de scribed as great, found himself on the other side of the camera lens for one of the few times in his long career when he agreed on short notice to play the hero's father in "Love and Money," which is being directed by James Toback from his own screenplay.

TOKYO, Jan. 24 (Reuters)-- Japan's exports to Iran rose sharply in December to the equivalent of $166 million, a 41.8 percent increase from November, the Finance Ministry said here today. Trade sources said the sharp rise in December exports was due partly to a rush in shipments before the Japanese Government made a decision on whether to join economic sanctions against Iran proposed by the United States.

While President Carter's State of the Union Address did not enumerate the Persian Gulf nations that the United States is seeking to keep secure, the principal oil-producing countries in the area, all Moslem, are Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iraq, Iran, United Arab Emirates and Qatar. In addition, the small island emirate of Bahrain is important to the oil trade as a financial center.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Mayor Koch said today that the nation's cities were being required to provide services mandated by Federal and state governments that then did not come up with the funds to pay for all the mandated actions.
A majority of the representatives on the Athletes Advisory Council to the United States Olympic Committee say they oppose an American boycott of the Moscow Olympics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Reuters)-- The Carter Administration said today it would sell 50 planes to Morocco to encourage a settlement of its war in the Western Sahara against guerrillas seeking independence. The aircraft, worth $235 million, will consist of 24 helicopters, 20 F-5E jets and six reconnaissance planes.
The New York City Health Department released on Wednesday the names of 27 food establishments that it said had violated the city's Health Code.

What was supposed to have been an intersectional basketball clash between Davidson of the Southern Conference and St. John's of the Big East Conference turned into a rout last night as the Redmen posted a 67-48 victory before 4,154 fans at Alumni Hall.

PAULINE KONER practices the choreographic virtues of a time before the current age of "terpsichore in sneakers," as Sally Banes, the critic, puts it, which is hardly surprising considering Miss Koner's long career as a modern-dance solo performer and associate of Doris Humphrey and Jose Limon.

"What's it good for?" asked Stuart Pivar incredulously, looking somewhat put off yesterday because the quintessence of his Moped-inspired electric Microcar was not immediately comprehended by his audience.

Like a glittering magnet, the soaring price of gold has sucked old jewelry from dresser drawers and drawn eager sellers to 47th Street, Manhattan's jewelry and diamond center. The object is to transform old jewelry into new cash. But as things turn out, it is hard to pin down the price, or even the weight of what one has to sell.

Mayor Koch announced yesterday that a new Staten Island ferryboat to begin service this spring would be named the Andrew Barberi, after the late Curtis High School football coach. A second boat, due next winter, will be named for Samuel I. Newhouse, the late publisher of The Staten Island Advance. Both men died last summer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Energy Secretary Charles W. Duncan Jr. said today that there was a continuing need for gasoline conservation, despite the fact that gasoline stocks were at an 11month high.

LANDOVER, Md., Jan. 24--The arms of George Johnson, the New Jersey Nets' starting center, seem to dangle to the knobby knees on his 6-foot-11inch, 220-pound frame. Sometimes those arms work to his disadvantage, such as when, in an enthusiastic effort to block an opponent's shot, he gives the other team an automatic 2 points because he is called for goaltending.

A former auditor at KLM Royal Dutch Airlines whose charges of improper payments set off investigations of the company by United States Government law enforcement agencies has abruptly left New York for the Netherlands Antilles under unusual circumstances.

President Carter's proposal to resume registration for the draft is above all a message to Moscow that he is determined to resist aggression. But it is also a minimum step to cope with actual military weakness.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24--An undulating, half-minute earthquake rocked San Francisco and much of northern California today, inflicting property damage and minor injury and forcing evacuation at a nuclear weapons research center at Livermore.

PARIS, Jan. 24--The gravity of President Carter's pledge to treat the Persian Gulf oilfields as "a vital American interest" to be defended by force if necessary was measured in Europe by a discreet high-level silence today. Governments accepted it as an American decision, not for them to judge in public comment.

Delta Air Lines reported yesterday that its earnings fell 38.1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1979 to $21.1 million, or $1.06 a share, from $34.1 million, or $1.71 a share, in the same period of 1978. Revenues increased in the 1979 period by 23 percent to $703.8 million, compared with $574.2 million a year earlier.
PANJPAI, Pakistan, Jan. 24 (Reuters) --Afghan refugees who fled into the barren regions of western Pakistan are falling sick because of the intense cold, refugee officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)--The House and Senate approved most-favored-nation trade status for China today, putting into effect a trade agreement with the world's most populous nation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Reuters)--The Civil Aeronautics Board said it had tentatively selected Minneapolis-St. Paul as the city to receive a new direct airline service to London.

WILHELM MEISTER (Rudiger Vogler) writes about what he experiences, not about what he ob serves. Perhaps because of this the young writer never seems surprised by the curious things people say to him. When he sets off to see the world, his mother says at the railroad station: "Please don't forget me. I've always been fond of you." Wilhelm's response is to think that he'd like to comb his hair when he's on the train.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 24 (Reuters)-- Revolutionary guards in the city of Yezd have sacrificed two camels in an appeal to heaven for the health of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, the official Pars press agency said today

Thomas M. Timlen, acting chief executive officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, accused participants in the foreign exchange and commodity markets yesterday of purposely starting rumors in order to increase their profits or cut their losses. These rumors, he said, have "growing spillover" in the Government bond market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Ever since the United States and the Soviet Union developed nuclear weapons and intercontinental missiles that made each capable of destroying the other, the major danger has not been that either would plan an atomic war but that they might stumble into a world disaster by fear and miscalculation.

As a witness described what he had seen after 20-year-old Guillermo Mora was run over by a train at a BMT elevated station in Brooklyn on a cold January night six years ago, a relative of the victim wept softly in the cramped courtroom.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24, (UPI)-- Top-seeded Jimmy Connors defeated Raul Ramirez of Mexico and secondseeded John McEnroe stopped Tim Gullikson tonight to join four other seeded players and the upset-minded John Sadri in the quarterfinals of the $250,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis championships.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 24 (Reuters)-- A spokesman for the Iranian militants holding 50 American hostages at the United States Embassy dismissed as propaganda today the exchange of messages between Iran and Panama yesterday about moves to extradite the deposed Shah from Panama.
A Queens real estate executive has offered to sell a Rego Park office building to the Federal Government as an alternative to a $92.7 million Federal office building proposed for downtown Jamaica.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (UPI)--Silvia Hanika upset Evonne Goolagong, the third-seeded player, and Martina Navratilova, seeded first, easily beat Tanya Harford tonight in advancing to the quarterfinals of a $200,000 tournament.

A $600 million Federal program that was supposed to encourage the growth of minority construction companies has failed to help the vast majority of such contractors in the New York City metropolitan area. And businessmen and government officials say that unless some additional special efforts are made, the smaller, poorer and less educationally prepared contractors are going to miss out again on additional millions of dollars the Administration wants to set aside for them.
Striking airline workers refused to obey a court order and return to work at Pan American World Airways facilities around the country yesterday, causing delays and more than 100 flight cancellations.

THE first of a projected series of shows saluting producers of Broadway musicals in the King Cole Room of the St. RegisSheraton Hotel was supposed to be a tribute to David Merrick. But Mr. Merrick decided that he did not want a tribute, so Harve Brosten's production, "Make Someone Happy," which will continue in the King Cole Room for the next two weeks, is now described merely as "a salute to 26 musicals."

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 24 (Reuters)-- Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini told Iranians by radio and television from his Teheran hospital bed today that his condition was "not bad." He called on the people not to let his hospitalization because of a heart ailment distract them from voting tomorrow in Iran's first presidential election.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Ronald Reagan joined in a Republican attack today on President Carter's State of the Union Address by charging that the Administration's failure to act "decisively" against Iran for seizing American hostages had invited the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan.

BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)--Terry O'Reilly's goal with three seconds left in the game gave the Boston Bruins a 4-3 victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight in a battle between the National Hockey League Adams Division leaders.

SHERBURNE, Vt., Jan. 24--As President Carter has risen in the polls amid the crises in Iran and Afghanistan, most of his rivals for the Presidency in both parties have been openly frustrated because foreign affairs have drawn attention from their candidacies.
TORONTO, Jan. 24--A battle by Bronfman interests for control of one of Canada's largest companies, Noranda Mines Ltd., could erupt at any time, according to knowledgeable analysts here.

"GUYANA--Cult of the Damned," which opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters, is a nervy, superfi cial re-creation of the events leading up to--and including--the mass suicide and murder of nearly a thousand people at Jonestown, Guyana, in the autumn of 1978.

TWO programs, each a new series of sorts, each dealing with human discovery, in one case, of the earth, in the other, of Mars, will appear on television Sunday night--unfortunately at the same time. Both are dramas, but their forte is not so much in the drama--which may be faulted-as in the thoughts, information and perceptions they offer.

LISBON, Jan. 24 (UPI)--The Portuguese Government announced today announced measures to cut back ties with the Soviet Union to protest its military intervention in Afghanistan and the banishment of Andrei D. Sakharov.

BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)--A judge of the Massachusetts Supreme Court ordered today that life-sustaining kidney dialysis treatments continue indefinitely for Earle Spring while a judge of a lower court decides whether to seek more medical evidence about the 78-year-old man's mental condition.

Snow or no snow, Wave Hill and much of its surrounding 28 acres in the Riverdale section of the Bronx will be open tomorrow and Sunday for a Winter Weekend Festival. Some activities, such as snowshoeing, will depend on the weather; most of the others will not.

SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Jan. 25 (UPI)--A court martial today sentenced former President Po Sun Yun to two years in jail and 17 other defendants were given prison terms ranging from one to four years for staging a protest rally last year.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 24--The South Koreans proposed today that a meeting of high officials of North and South Korea be held Feb. 6 to prepare for the first encounter between the Prime Ministers of the two Governments since Korea was divided in 1945.

KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 24 (Reuters)--The Soviet-backed Afghan Government of Babrak Karmal, in power for four weeks, appears to be quietly trying to win back the confidence of a Moslem people shattered by violence, arbitrary arrests and destruction of its traditions, Western diplomats here report.
An ABC News-Harris survey of Republican and independent voters shows George Bush in a tie with Ronald Reagan in support for the Republican Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Three years ago, Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, received a report on the global military situation that viewed the Persian Gulf as the most likely area for a confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI)--The United States is reducing its naval force in the Indian Ocean while the Soviet Union has increased its presence there, Pentagon officials said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24--Late last night it looked as though former Gov. Ronald Reagan had won a victory in a dispute over the proportional division of California's Republican convention delegation, but today that victory looked shaky.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 24--The Arab world's first reaction to President Carter's assertion yesterday that the United States would provide a security umbrella for the Persian Gulf appeared to be cool.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI)--The Senate approved a 15 percent increase in education benefits for millions of veterans of the Vietnam period today, ignoring a warning by Senator Edmund S. Muskie that the $800 million cost would "bust" the Federal budget.

A Manhattan man with a history of prostitution-related crimes was indicted yesterday on charges of acting as a pimp for a 14-year-old girl. The Manhattan District Attorney's office said the accused, 25-year-old Andre Rivera of Manhattan, had forced the girl to work in a Times Square escort service that was actually a house of prostitution.
WINAMAC, Ind., Jan. 24--The state of Indiana today defeated an attempt by the Ford Motor Company to bar testimony by a controversial witness for the state in the Pinto trial.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--With its formidable needles, tough skin and ability to flourish in drought and extremes of heat and cold, the cactus may be one of the hardier members of the vegetable kingdom. But the Government found it necessary today to step in to protect some cactuses from extinction.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 (UPI)-- Striking delivery truck drivers at The Philadelphia Journal ratified a threeyear contract today by vote of 52 to 3. The management said that the newspaper would be back on the stands tomorrow.

PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 24 (Reuters)--Customs officials here made a discovery yesterday of almost five tons of hashish and 33 pounds of opium, valued at more than $3 million, in two trucks and a car. Five occupants of the vehicles were arrested.

FOR more than 10 years, Frank Kermode has been editing and the Viking Press has been publishing the "Modern Masters" series, a string of long essays or short books devoted to people "who have changed and are changing the life and thought of our age."

Gold for January delivery closed on the Comex yesterday at $681, up $21 from Wednesday, while the Republic National Bank quoted bullion late in the day at $680, up $20. Gold traded within a range of $665 to $712 at the bank during the day.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)--Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, has introduced a bill to repeal a ban on admission of suspected homosexual aliens into the United States.
BOSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)--Commissioner Bowie Kuhn refused today "to rule out the possibility of a major league baseball strike or lockout" this spring.

LAST night's New York Philharmonic program conducted by Zubin Mehta could not be ac cused of lack of contrast. It had an example of early Romanticism, a Late Romantic violin concert, an example of one side of American modernism in the 1950's, and a world premiere.

The basic measure of the nation's money supply rose by $1 billion in the week ended Jan. 16, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The unexpected rise led led some market participants to expect the Fed to tighten credit in coming weeks.
The new owners of the New York Mets conceded last night that they faced a monumental task in rebuilding a last-place team but insisted that "the dollar commitment is there."

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 24--Venezuelan legislators unanimously condemned the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan last night and voted support for the recent United Nations General Assembly resolution calling for an immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Soviet troops from that country.
Texaco Inc. reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 62.6 percent, and the Gulf Oil Corporation announced a 54.4 percent increase.
Supplies of distillate fuels fell by 3.4 million barrels in the week ended Jan. 18, to 220.1 million, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The Federal Communications Commission, in the most sweeping disciplinary move in its history, today stripped RKO General Inc. of licenses for three major television stations, in Boston, New York and Los Angeles.
TOKYO, Jan. 24--Japan today hailed President Carter's strong stand, in his State of the Union Address, against the aggression of the Soviet Union.

Ayatollah Khomeini quickly made himself the enemy America loves to hate. Now the Russians are turning him into an ally we hate to love. And the President, confronted with a double-bind in the Middle East, has fired off some tough talk in his State of the Union Message. But on reflection, it doesn't sound so tough at all. If the situation is as serious as Mr. Carter says, ...
About $530 million a year in government funds goes to house people on welfare in New York City. It amounts to 40 percent of the total spent for welfare assistance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The White House said today that some young men would be required to register soon for the draft but officials were uncertain about how many, of what ages, or when--or whether young women would be included.

Gold futures prices fell the $50 daily trading limit for deliveries in coming months, while the spot January contract made a modest $21 gain. Market analysts said the deferrred deliveries were moving to catch up with the drastic price drops gold underwent earlier this week, when prices fell by $143 an ounce in one day.

MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (AP)--The Los Angeles Kings' high-scoring line of Marcel Dionne, Charlie Simmer and Dave Taylor has been elected by the Professional Hockey Writers Association to the Prince of Wales team for the National Hockey League's All-Star Game.

The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation yesterday reported sharply lower earnings for the fourth quarter of 1979, down 47 percent to $7.9 million, or $1.83 a share, from $14.9 million, or $3.76 a share, in the final quarter of 1978.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24--Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena Bonner, joined eight other human-rights activists today in a statement condemning the Soviet Government for "suppressing the independence of Afghanistan."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)--New orders received by United States factories for durable goods rose a modest six-tenths of 1 percent in December, but auto orders continued to drop, the Commerce Department said today.
If Nelson Doubleday Jr. emerged as the most visible principal in yesterday's sale of the New York Mets, one of the key men behind the package was John O. Pickett Jr.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Reuters)-- United States gold production last year fell 9 percent to 910,000 ounces, but gold exports tripled to 15.6 million ounces, the Government said today, as a result of heavy sales of gold from Government stocks.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 24 (Reuters)--The European Economic Community will give more than $20 million in aid to Pakistan to help it cope with refugees from Afghanistan, officials said today. Of the total, $14 million will be in cash and $3.7 million in food.

PISCATAWAY, N.J., Jan. 24-- There were many minutes tonight when Syracuse did not look like the No. 5 team in the country, the ranking the Orangemen have in this week's United Press International poll. During those times, Syracuse did not even look like No. 6, its rank in The Associated Press poll.

THERE was a time when exhibitions of new art came over from London almost as regularly as Cunard liners docked on the Hudson River piers. But that era is long since gone. No longer does New York trouble to keep up with every new reputation on the British art scene. Perhaps our horizons have narrowed. Or is it that the British scene is now less interesting than it used to be?

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 24 (AP) --President Tito, recovering from the amputation of his left leg, has begun rehabilitation therapy and met with high Yugoslav officials, the official press agency, Tanyug, reported today.

Andrei D. Sakharov's editor in the United States, Ashbel Green of Alfred A. Knopf, yesterday condemned his internal exile, and said he hoped writers and publishers would join in condemning what he called "this savage disregard of human dignity and the rule of law."
One rare event will be replaced in New York City next month by two that are almost equally rare.

AMERICANA auctions attract the largest attendance and most enthusiastic bidding of all sales held at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street. Coming up are crowd-pleaser events offering a staggering variety of wares in about 1,700 lots that fill two thick catalogues.

ON the surface, Jerome Robbins's "Afternoon of a Faun" is a deceptively simple tale of a boy, a girl and their ballet barre. But there is a little room for interpretation and, in her first performance of the role, Heather Watts gave the girl an interesting new look when the New York City Ballet presented the ballet on Tuesday at the New York State Theater.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 24 (UPI) --The United States Gymnastics Federation announced today that Coach Ernestine Weaver of the University of Florida had been named head coach for the United States women's gymnastics team at this year's Olympic Games.

BACK when he was a teen-ager in Falls Church, Va., Martin Vidnovic used to fantasize about growing up to be like Sergio Franchi--wearing a dinner jacket and addressing his powerful lyric baritone and charm to awed, adoring audiences in fashionable supper clubs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Politically as well as diplomatically, President Carter's State of the Union Address was a forceful stroke that has added for the moment to the momentum of his victory Monday night in Iowa and complicated the task of his opponents.

IF the reputation of Arthur B. Dove (1880-1946) has yet to settle down, it is because his was a many sided art, as to which the question "How good was Dove?" invites the counter-question "Which Dove?" Be-...

EVERY year, musicians, impresarios and critics look about to find important musical anniversaries to celebrate-- remember the big Mozart bash back in 1956 on the occasion of the composer's 200th birthday, or Beethoven's bicentennial in 1970? No doubt 1985 will witness a staggering number of Bach and Handel performances when these two grand figures of the Baroque Age turn 300. Such round-number observances ...
Ethel Kravitz, who served seven years in prison for the slaying of her husband in 1958, died Tuesday of a heart attack in her apartment in Jackson Heights, Queens. She was 67 years old.

The National Health Service Corps is preparing to send seven more dentists to New York City, doubling the number it has in poor neighborhoods where there are overwhelming dental problems and not a single local dentist to deal with them.

Robby Benson, the actor with the bluest eyes this side of Paul Newman and the aw-shucks country boy manner, is perhaps best known for his film roles as the young man who jumped off the Tallahatchie bridge in "Ode to Billy Joe" and as the hotdog basketball star in "One on One."
A man sitting on a Queens jury broke his right hand during deliberations that led yesterday to the convictions of the two defendants for murder and robbery.

TORONTO, Jan. 24 (Reuters)--Some Olympic events could be held in the fouryear-old facilities in Montreal if this year's Games were shifted from Moscow to several Western sites, Prime Minister Joe Clark said today.

The State Senate Select Committee on Crime said yesterday that there were "significant gaps in the security arrangements" for next month's Olympic Games at Lake Placid, N.Y., and laid much of the blame on the state police.

As an appeals court deliberated his "right to die," Brother Joseph Charles Fox, a Marianist teacher who had been kept breathing only by a respirator, died last night of cardiac arrest at Nassau Hospital in Mineola. He was 83 years old and had been in a coma since undergoing surgery Oct. 2.

A four-year study of men treated for alcoholism has confirmed an earlier finding that some alcoholics are able to return to social drinking. But for most, the study showed, total abstinence seems to be the surest path to a long-lasting cure.
MADRID, Jan. 24--The Communist Parties of France, Italy and Spain, in relatively diplomatic language, have criticized the banishment of Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident leader.

President Carter's decision to revitalize the Selective Service System evoked both anger and approval yesterday from college students across the nation who were 11 or 12 years old when the draft was abolished and who are now considering for the first time the possibility of fighting in a war.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 24 (UPI) --Didier Pironi of France, driving a Ligier, set an unofficial track record today during practice runs at the Interlagos circuit for Sunday's Grand Prix of Brazil. Pironi's time of 2 minutes 23.06 seconds topped the previous unofficial mark, 2:23.07, set last year by Jacques Laffite, Pironi's teammate and compatriot.

THE outrageous and irrepressible figure of Punchinello--the archetypal tragicomic clown spawned by the theatrical tradition of the commedia dell'arte-- is one of the great mythic inventions of the European imagination, and there is no more engaging or comprehensive account of his multifarious adventures than the one to be found in the voluminous series of drawings that Domenico Tiepolo devoted to this theme in the 18th century.
ALL three works offered by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater were re workings of older choreography.
The Amdahl Corporation reported yesterday a 96.6 percent drop in earnings for the final quarter of 1979. The company's full-year profit decline was 65 percent.

LONDON--President Carter's recent discovery that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini is not a member of the Rotary Club was bound to cause controversy in Europe, and not only among those who don't greatly care for the Rotary Club; an excess of realism in the White House is all very well, but it musn't be allowed to get out of hand.

WHENEVER Gordon Davidson comes to New York with a new play that originated at the Mark Taper Forum, the adventurous theater he runs in Los An geles, audiences can expect to see something out of the ordinary.

The President's call for quick passage of new intelligence laws is justified but not because Iran and Afghanistan were intelligence failures. No one seriously claims that Iran was "lost" because of some postWatergate shackle on covert C.I.A. operations or that unrestricted wiretapping of American citizens would have given earlier warning of Soviet aggression in Afghanistan.

Oliver Weerasinghe, a former Ambassador to the United States from Sri Lanka and a former member of the United Nations Secretariat in New York, died in Colombo Sunday of a heart attack, according to news reports. He was 73 years old.

ALL the stage is a world of enchantment in Andrei Serban's production of "As You Like It" in the Annex at La Mama. Mr. Serban first presented his version of the comedy on location in a forest in France.

"SPELLING things out," says Michael Meltsner's narrator, "doesn't necessarily show respect for a reader." It may be no more than "the substitution of time for metaphor." "I'd rather dart about in confusion," he continues, "than stand around waiting for something to happen."
The New York Times Company has bought a building and site that for five years have housed its satellite printing plant in Carlstadt, N.J.

The Commodity Exchange acted yesterday to limit trading in copper futures contracts to prevent what its officials termed was the "faint possibility of an attempt to squeeze or corner the market." The exchange put limits on holdings and doubled cash margins for speculators, effective this Monday morning.

LONDON, Jan. 24--Britain announced today a broad program of diplomatic reprisals against the Soviet Union, including the suspension of ministerial and other high-level contacts, to protest the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan.

The 10th year of "Lyrics and Lyricists"--the joyous series at the 92d Street Y, in which writers who have created the lyrics for some of the most celebrated scores for Broadway and Hollywood musicals discuss their craft and demonstrate their songs--will open Sunday with a program that has been rehearsed in its entirety at the Neurological Institute of ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center.

Delegates from 10 leading Protestant denominations took a big step toward ecumenical unity yesterday by approving a document that outlines a proposed form of the ministry that includes bishops and recognized lay ministers.
The two-month bidding war for purchasing the New York Mets ended yesterday when controlling interest in the team was sold by the Payson family to Doubleday Company, the Park Avenue book publisher.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--After three days of assessing his poor showing in the Iowa caucuses, Senator Edward M. Kennedy today abruptly canceled plans for a weekend campaign swing through New England and said he would make a "major" policy speech here Monday.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--New York State's colleges and universities will face serious cutbacks, possible layoffs and tuition increases under Governor Carey's new budget, officials in public and private higher education warned yesterday.

John J. Cronin, who headed the New York Police Department's missing-persons bureau for 18 years, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital after a brief illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Jefferson Valley, N.Y.
Signaling their complete break with Mayor Koch, Liberal Party leaders now say they hope their party will serve as a "fulcrum for a good-government coalition" opposed to his re-election next year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Despite Administration objections, Congress is moving to give Americans a new tax break: partial exemption from taxes on interest income.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 24 (Reuters)--A special conference of Islamic foreign ministers to discuss the Soviet Union's intervention in Afghanistan is expected to be postponed by a day in response to a request from Iran, political sources here said today.
BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Jan. 24 (AP)-- Nate S. Shapero, founder of the Cunningham drugstore chain, died yesterday in a hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 24 (AP)-- Jesse Owens, the track phenomenon of the 1936 Olympic Games, has been admitted to the University of Arizona Health Sciences Center here for treatment of lung cancer, his doctor said today.

BONN, Jan. 24--Of all the agonies the Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt is experiencing through the breakdown of detente, the most acute involves the decision it must make on... whether to go along with President Carter's urging of an Olympic boycott.

To help maintain transit and commuter fares, New York State's Power Authority exempted the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday from any part of a new $51.8 million-a-year increase in rates for electricity from its Indian Point 3 nuclear and Astoria 6 oil-fired plants.

ABC Sports announced yesterday that it had acquired the exclusive United States rights to televise the 1984 Winter Olympics in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. The purchase price was not disclosed, but ABC paid $15.5 million for the United States rights to the 1980 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, N.Y. from Feb. 12 to 24.

The most valuable American private collection of art and antiques ever to be auctioned--the collection of the late Edgar William and Bernice Chrysler Garbisch--will go under the hammer in May in a major series of sales conducted in New York and Maryland by Sotheby Parke Bernet. Included are major works by Picasso, Van Gogh, Cezanne and Gauguin and Renoir.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The Federal Government has learned of plans by industry in the United States to dispose of poisonous wastes by shipping them overseas to developing countries and is concerned about the implications of such traffic, Carter Administration officials disclosed today

The General Electric Company reported yesterday that it had a 5.1 percent increase in its 1979 fourth-quarter profits to $382 million, or $1.68 a share, from $363.6 million, or $1.59 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1978, based on preliminary and unaudited results.

In recognition of his humanitarianism and contribution to the world of the printed word, James A. Michener, author of "Chesapeake" and other works, is the recipient of the 1980 Franklin Award for Distinguished Service given by the Printing Industries of Metropolitan New York to individuals who have "personififed the philosophy and public service of Benjamin Franklin."

DETROIT, Jan. 24 (AP)--The number of auto industry workers on layoffs will be sharply reduced next week, dipping below 200,000 for the first time in two weeks, according to company announcements today.
GRAND PRAIRIE, Tex., Jan. 24 (UPI)--Jim Stefanich, a 38-year-old bowler, overcame difficulties in the second round last night and moved into the lead of the $100,000 Quaker State open.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI)--The Governors of Nevada and Utah said today that they did not want the MX missile system in their states without firm guarantees that the quality of life would not suffer.

Bond yields soared to record levels yesterday as prices plunged in response to the President Carter's State of the Union Address delivered Wednesday night. Several other negatives also weighed heavily on the fixedincome market.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24--The official Soviet press agency Tass denounced as an "absurdity" today President Carter's warning that the United States regarded the Persian Gulf region as one of its vital interests and would use force if necessary to repel an outside threat to it.

The New England ski jumping championships, scheduled for Salisbury, Conn., today and tomorrow, have been canceled because of lack of snow.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 25 Yun Po Sun, the 83-year-old former South Korean President, was sentenced today to two years in prison by a military court that convicted him of breaking a martial law decree banning street demonstrations.

WASHINGTON Hundreds of thousands of former mental patients have been released from hospitals across the nation since 1963 under a Federal reform policy that recognized that in some cases institutions did as much harm as good.

Terry O'Reilly of the Boston Bruins was hit with an eight-game suspension and two teammates, Peter McNab and Mike Milbury, were suspended for six games by the National Hockey League last night for brawling with spectators at Madison Square Garden last month. KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 25 Local pride was served, along with champagne and hors d'oeuvres, at last night's gala opening of the Tennessee Williams Performing Arts Center at Florida Keys Community College.
Precious metals continued their price plunge on the nation's futures exchanges yesterday, with gold plummeting as much as $50 an ounce while silver posted losses of up to $3 an ounce.

Allen Curtis Lewis was acquitted last night of charges that he pushed Renee Katz, a 17-year-old music student, into the path of a Manhattan subway train last June 7. Miss Katz's right hand, which was severed by the train, was later reattached in a 16-hour operation at Bellevue Hospital.
