Matthias Hohner founded the German harmonica company bearing his name in 1857, and by the turn of the century the company was selling its products in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 After losing favor among many evangelical leaders in the past three years, President Carter this week made a two-day blitz of witnessing, embracing and grits for breakfast in an attempt to soothe representatives of what they assert are a total of 80 million Christian evangelicals.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 A tip from a Lynwood, Calif., savings and loan association officer two and a half years ago has resulted in the arrest of eight persons who, the local authorities say, may have collected the largest amount of money ever collected fraudulently in the national program of Aid to Families with Dependent Children. Two suspects are still being sought.
LOS ANGELES Nine months ago, Sherry Lansing, then senior vice president of Columbia Pictures, said she doubted whether "in my working lifetime, I'll see a woman as president of a movie company."

DALLAS, Jan. 27 (UPI) Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson, a former Dallas Cowboy linebacker, said today that he would ask Tom Landry, the Cowboys' coach, for forgiveness and hoped that he would be allowed to return to the team.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27 (UPI) Lynn Patrick, a National Hockey League all-star with the New York Rangers in the 1930's and 1940's and the first coach and general manager of the St. Louis Blues, died of an apparent heart attack last night.

Nearly 700 people have been given high-paying jobs at Board of Education headquarters and in local school districts through a hiring system that bypasses Civil Service law, often requires minimal qualifications and rewards some holders of administrative jobs with educational licenses and the promise of tenure, according to school documents.
BAY SHORE, L.I. HAVING shot nothing during a duck-hunting trip on Great South Bay the previous day, Guy Coheleach and I turned to a less-elusive prey the blue crab.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 27 President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan urged Islamic nations today to unite in demanding the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan. He also asked for a collective defense arrangement to ward off future invasions of Moslem nations.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (Reuters) The Peoples Gas Company said that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Exeter Company of Denver for about $150 million, consisting of 1.6 million shares of Peoples common stock, $69 million in cash and notes and the assumption of Exeter's long-term debt.

George S. Harsh, a convicted murderer who won a pardon after helping to save the life of a fellow inmate and who later became a World War II hero, an author and a spokesman against capital punishment, died Friday in Toronto. He was 72 years old.

AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 26 When Rosalynn Carter was campaigning here yesterday, one of her main stops was a meeting of several hundred teachers at a local high school. Standing in the rear of the school cafeteria, waiting for Mrs. Carter to arrive, Peter Meagher explained why he was getting more involved in politics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 The Republican Party has accused President Carter of breaking 227 campaign promises in his first three years in office, more than onethird of the pledges that the White House officially acknowledged early in the Administration.

FOR nearly an hour, Tom Watson had been hitting golf balls on the practice range and now, with the setting sun gilding the Pacific alongside the Torrey Pines course near San Diego, he was practicing chip shots to the putting green in the twilight. Behind one of the cups, his caddie, Bruce Edwards, formed a target with his sneakers.

DILI, East Timor--Slowly and painfully this former Portuguese colony, annexed by Indonesia after an invasion in 1975, is heading from war and famine toward the state of marginal survival that was its lot through four centuries of colonial rule.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 27 Confusion and disappointment reigned today at the Israeli-Egyptian border as tourists tried, mostly in vain, to take advantage of the opening of the frontier between the two former enemies.
Larry Reid, the suburban Minneapolis auto dealer credited by the Chrysler Corporation with originating the most novel element in its new sales campaign, is a salesman who speaks in superlatives.

DENVER, Jan. 27 (AP) It appears that George McGinnis, the Denver Nuggets' third leading scorer and second leading rebounder this season, may be between jobs.

Did the accident at Three Mile Island come close, after all, to a meltdown of the nuclear fuel core? That frightening possibility is suggested by the latest official investigation, conducted for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission by a team headed by Mitchell Rogovin, a Washington lawyer.

Saudi Arabia, the largest supplier of oil to the United States, has decided to raise the price of its light crude by $2 a barrel, or about 5 cents a gallon, according to oil industry sources in New York. The new price of $26 a barrel is an increase of more than 8 percent and will be retroactive to Jan. 1, they said.

PEKING, Jan. 27 In the winter of 1944, a small group of American Army observers stationed at Yanan, the Chinese Communists' wartime capital, made a secret recommendation that the United States consider supplying military aid to the Red Army to help fight against Japan.

The offering to newspapers and broadcasters by United Press International to join in a new limited partnership closes Wednesday, and so far, U.P.I. has received commitments for about 60 percent of the offering, according to sources at the news agency.
Pizza Hut, the Pepsico fast-food chain, has decided to review its relationship with Foote, Cone Belding, Chicago, its national ad agency for about three years. The ad budget is about $15 million.

The Rev. Dr. William Sloane Coffin Jr., senior minister of the Riverside Church, made public yesterday the contents of a letter he received Saturday from Robert C. Ode, a 64-year-old retired Foreign Service officer who is being held hostage by Iranians at the United States Embassy in Teheran.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 Andrei D. Sakharov is under police supervision and has been forbidden to communicate by mail or phone with foreigners or even relatives abroad, according to a friend who arrived here today from Gorky. The Soviet physicist, a leading human rights advocate, was banished to Gorky Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 When President Carter's Cabinet secretaries met at the White House for a preview of the Federal budget that is to be submitted to Congress tomorrow, James T. McIntyre Jr., director of the Office of Management and Budget, informed them in somber tones that Mr. Carter had decided at the last minute to cut spending by a staggering $100 billion. The secretaries stared in disbelief.

The Juilliard Opera Center will present the premiere of "Feathertop," an opera by Edward Barnes, next month. Mr. Barnes is a 22-year-old composition student of Vincent Persichetti at Juilliard.

KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 27 (Reuters) Political slogans and portraits of past and present Afghan leaders began to disappear from the streets of Kabul today as the country's Marxist rulers sought the support of the Moslem population.

Conservation efforts and mild winter weather have caused such a drop in sales of home heating oil that many oil dealers in New York City and on Long Island have increased their prices to offset their losses in sales, according to a survey made public yesterday.

New York State park officials have decided to blast a large section of rock from Terrapin Point, overlooking the 168-foothigh Horseshoe Falls, to improve safety conditions at what used to be a principal observation site at Niagara Falls.

BILBAO, Spain, Jan. 27 (Reuters) The Basque separatist guerrilla group E.T.A. claimed responsibility today for the killing of a bar owner and a gravedigger in separate attacks in the northern region last week.
ROME, Jan. 27 (UPI) Pope John Paul II is personally involved in intense but quiet diplomatic efforts to calm tensions between the United States and the Soviet Union, Vatican sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27--The TMS-65 is a large, new Soviet vehicle that is easy to identify. It is a turbojet aircraft engine on a turntable, mounted on a truck; towed behind the turntable is a large tank of chemicals to be injected into the hot exhaust from the jet engine. You cannot mistake the TMS-65 for any other military device--it's one of a kind.

BOSTON Joel Schnee, an American who is ballet director of the Kassel Theater in West Germany, was named winner of the $5,000 Boston Ballet Award in the second annual international Choreographers Showcase competition sponsored by the Boston company.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 It was supposed to be the "limp and whimper" show in today's final of the $250,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis championships. Jimmy Connors, the defender, was nursing a groin injury and John McEnroe, his challenger, had been complaining vehemently about the officiating.

LANDOVER, Md., Jan. 27 Mike Gartner and Bengt Gustafsson set a National Hockey League record by scoring two goals in the first 30 seconds of the second period to spark the Washington Capitals to a 7-1 victory over the New York Islanders tonight. The Capitals set a team record by scoring six times in the period.

ELKHART, Ind., Jan. 27 (AP) Five persons were killed and six others were seriously injured early today in a fire that sent smoke pouring through a downtown hotel. Some residents of the hotel jumped from third-floor windows to escape.

Henry M. He was 58 years old.
In the year since Abolhassan BaniSadr returned to Iran from his self-imposed exile in France, his fortunes have often mirrored the turbulence and uncertainty of Iran.

IF Franco Brusati's "To Forget Venice" were a more appealing movie, it might seem mysterious instead of obscure. As it is, Mr. Brusati's film requires a lot of deciphering, and plenty of patience, too. Whatever secrets lurk beneath this pretty and bewildering surface, they feel like more trouble than they're worth. Mr. Brusati offers extravagant amounts of smoke, but no evidence of a real fire.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 27 Robert Mugabe, the former public school teacher who has commanded a guerrilla army against white rule in this country for much of the past decade, came home today to campaign for the nation's leadership under black rule. He was given a near-riotous reception by 150,000 or more supporters.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 27 (AP) Marvin Schwartz, a veteran drag-racing driver, died Saturday of injuries suffered when his car veered across the Tucson Dragway track and flipped several times during a qualifying run Friday.

SALAMANCA, N.Y. Not so long ago, visitors to this small river community 60 miles south of Buffalo were informed by signs, by restaurant place mats, by word of mouth that they were in "the only city in the United States on an Indian reservation."
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 Senator Bob Dole flew back to Washington today from Topeka, Kan., still pondering whether to drop out of the race for the Republican Presidential nomination.

TOKYO, Monday, Jan. 28 (AP) The dollar opened slightly higher, at 240 yen, today on the Tokyo foreign-exchange market. In quiet early trading, it stayed in the 239.80-240.10 range, compared with Friday's closing of 239.30 yen. In Hong Kong, meanwhile, gold opened at $645.27 an ounce, down from $654.03, than advanced to $647.02.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 27 Olympic Village, the athlete housing complex built for the 1980 Winter Games here, officially opens tomorrow, but not with a customary bang and brass band.

A memorial service for Clark M. Eichelberger, retired director of the American Association for the United Nations, who died Saturday at the age of 83, will be held Feb. 15 at the Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street.

The world's toughest annual pair contest ended in London yesterday afternoon in a notable victory for a Scottish partnership. The winners of The Sunday Times's championship, in a field of 16 star partnerships from both sides of the Atlantic, were Barnet Shenkin and Victor Goldberg.

New York City's Investigation Department has gathered evidence that Eugene F. Mastropieri may have committed felonies under the state's Election Law by not living in the county he represents as a City Councilman. PRETORIA, South Africa, Jan. 27 (Reuters) The seizure of a suburban bank that ended with the death of five people appears to have left South Africa's ruling white minority wondering whether black opposition to segregation is entering a new and violent phase.

When the National Hockey League suspended four players without pay for a total of 30 games and handed out 19 fines last Friday, it appeared that the league might be instituting a tough new policy to abate violence in the sport. WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Barely a month after a convention of coal miners gave him extraordinary and successive votes of confidence, the new president of the United Mine Workers is translating that mandate into new respect for the beleaguered union from the coal industry.

Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan has decided not to seek the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York and instead will endorse Representative Elizabeth Holtzman.

The financing calendar remains active this week in both the corporate and tax-exempt sectors of the fixed-income market.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 27 Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, the Economic and Financial Affairs Minister who apparently has been elected President of Iran by an overwhelming majority, said today that the major responsibility for ending the crisis over the hostages being held in the American Embassy lay with the United States.
DENVER, Jan. 27 (AP) Phil Esposito scored from the slot with just 24 seconds remaining tonight as the New York Rangers battled to a 3-3 tie with the Colorado Rockies in a National Hockey League game.
BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Larry Bird, Boston's star rookie, scored 36 points today in his top effort as a pro and the Celtics beat San Diego, 131-108. It was the sixth straight loss for the Clippers.

THE pas de deux on television today is being performed by Agnes de Mille(with words) and the Joffrey Ballet (with footwork), and if you miss this delightful 90 minutes you should be sentenced to 13 weeks of looking at nothing but pilot films of situation comedies that will never get on the air.

HONOLULU, Jan. 27 (AP) Chuck Muncie of New Orleans ran for two touchdowns and threw a 25-yard halfback option pass to Tony Hill of Dallas for another score today to lead the National Conference to a 37-27 victory over the American Conference in the Pro Bowl.
BONN, Jan. 27--Europe's new currency system is ending its first year of operation back where it started--embroiled in disputes over its value.

Congress, the President and the agencies themselves have worked together on controls to prevent any recurrence of abuses and rogue adventures.

Major industrial sectors showed a mixed trend in earnings for the fourth quarter of 1979, with the oil industry the only clear winner. While some industries were victims of foreign exchange losses, declines in product demand, and rising inflation, energy costs and interest rates, many companies reported increased profits and dividends.

The New York City Planning Commission has come up with the most sensible and probably the quickest way finally to wire Queens for cable television. ON Dec. 13, 1977, the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company, after many years of omitting divi dends on its common stock, declared a whopper. This immediately caused an uproar among the B.'s debenture holders, who got no notice and thus no time to convert their debentures into common stock and participate in the dividend.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The $142.7 billion Defense Department budget that President Carter sent to Congress today calls for an increase in military spending of 3.3 percent after adjustment to account for inflation and projects a steadily rising military budget over the next five years.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Jan. 28 -- Since November, people here have awakened almost daily to another installment of a scandal that, drawing on the nickname of their beloved University of New Mexico teams, has been dubbed "Lobogate." And the installments show no sins of abating.

E. Burke Giblin, former chairman and chief executive officer of the WarnerLambert Company, a manufacturer of pharmaceuticals and optical and medical products, died Sunday after a long illness at his home in North Palm Beach, Fla. He was 66 years old and also lived in Marblehead, Mass.
Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91-day and the 182-day maturities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The Senate Banking Committee heard an assistant Treasury Secretary praise New York City today for planning to balance its budget a year ahead of schedule, but it also heard differing views on how much the city would have to increase its workers' salaries in upcoming labor talks.

WASHINGTON--The Soviet invasion of Afghanistan has been described as dealing the death blow to SALT II. No need now to worry about killer amendments or whether Presidential candidates will find support of the treaty limiting strategic arms a plus or a minus. But surprise, surprise! SALT II is alive!

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Carter Administration officials have decided to go into the world petroleum market to purchase about 100,000 barrels of oil a day for placement in the Federal stockpiles in salt domes in Louisiana.

The "Paul Simon and Ed Koch Show" made its debut on morning radio yesterday. Mr. Simon, the singersongwriter, wasn't in the studio, but Mr. Koch, the Mayor-performer, was, and that was the title he chose for his one-hour bow as an early morning music man.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 28 (AP)--A Lebanese admirer of Iran's Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini briefly hijacked a Middle East Airlines jet today to try to push Islamic countries to resolve the disappearance of an Iranian Shiite Moslem leader.
WOMEN as a group may be no match for men in brute strength, but when it comes to the diseases that kill people, women are decidedly the stronger sex.

A suit against New York City and some of its officials that charged they had deliberately misled buyers of city securities during the worst of the fiscal crisis was dismissed by a Federal judge yesterday.

DEDUCTIONS, like charity, begin at home. In recent years, however, one homey deduction has become much harder to obtain: a business-expense deduction for the cost of maintaining an office at home. Congress severely restricted those who qualify. You cannot qualify, for instance, if you work at home but have a "normal" office elsewhere. By and large, the deduction is permitted only if one has no other place of business.

A nine-month study of New York's cultural life assembled by some of the city's leading arts authorities has found New York to be a principal victim of cuts in the state's arts budget and the Federal Government's new direction in giving support on the basis of geography rather than on artistic quality.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The productivity of businesses and workers in the United States during the fourth quarter of 1979 fell at an annual rate of 1.6 percent, the Labor Department reported today. It was the fourth consecutive quarter that the rate had declined and signaled continued high inflation.
TOKYO, Jan. 28--Japan's army chief of staff resigned today and 10 other senior military officials were disciplined in connection with exposure of a Soviet spy network in the Defense Agency.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 28--Philip Dawes Martindale, Fourth Commandant of Santiago's volunteer firemen, was driving to his job as finance manager at a shoe-polish company when his radio monitor reported a fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Despite the prospect of using at least $3 billion to cushion the impact on farm prices of the curtailment of grain to the Soviet Union, the Agriculture Department is requesting authority to spend $924 million less in the fiscal year 1981 than in the current fiscal year.
THE honeymoon may be over, but the fighting hasn't begun. In other words, Zubin Mehta seems safely ensconced in the middle of his second season as music director of the New York Philharmonic.
WHAT has become of the home chemistry lab, whose malodorous and occasionally alarming experiments brightened the lives of many an American adolescent in bygone years?

EDDIE HEYWOOD led a sextet in the 1940's that became one of the most popular instrumental groups of the day. It is a tightly stylized group that was developed out of Mr. Heywood's solo piano treatment of "Begin the Beguine," although, with the sextet, Mr. Heywood's piano playing was subordinate to the group's sound.
Net operating earnings of the National Bank of North America plummeted by 49 percent to $2.79 million last quarter from $5.53 million in the fourth quarter of 1978, the bank announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI)--It would take from seven to 21 months to get a standby gasoline rationing plan into operation if an emergency arose now, Hazel Rollins, administrator of the Economic Regulatory Administration, told a Senate energy subcommittee today.

The Weyerhaeuser Company said yesterday that its earnings climbed 15.1 percent to $109.5 million, or 85 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with earnings of $95.1 million, or 74 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1978.
The per capita share of the $939.4 billion Federal debt projected by President Carter's budget is $4,229.
The credit markets, after declining forcefully for two weeks, continued in their slump yesterday with prices moving down further. Trading activity slackened, however.
The Soviet airline Aeroflot announced in New York yesterday that its flight from Moscow to Dulles International Airport in Washington today had been canceled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Brig. Gen. Martin Francis Scanlon of the Army, retired, and one of the first military aviators, died of heart failure Saturday at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 90 years old.

CHENGDU, China, Jan. 26--Sichuan Province, with a largely rural population of nearly 100 million, has reduced its annual rate of population growth to sixthtenths of one percent, local officials say, a feat unequaled in any other developing country.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 28-- Secretary General Kurt Waldheim is planning a series of new moves aimed at speeding the release of the American hostages in Teheran, United Nations sources said today. Among the moves is tentative selection of a commission to inquire into what Iran asserts to be its grievances.

The budget reflects the Administration's windfall profit tax proposal, which is designed to capture a part of the windfall profits of domestic oil producers that result from decontrol of domestic oil prices and rapid increases in world oil prices.
IT was a delicious Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater. The New York City Ballet presented the first "Bournonville Divertissements" of the season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--In vivid contrast to the stringencies he would impose on many other aspects of American life in his new budget, the President is prepared to give a substantial lift to scientific research and technological development.

HONOLULU, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The National Football League's Pro Bowl game will be played here in Aloha Stadium again next year, Commissioner Pete Rozelle announced today. The annual all-star contest will be played on Feb. 1, 1981.

The chambered nautilus, a mollusk known for its beautiful spiral shell, can fill compartments of its shell with gas for buoyancy and swim at ocean depths of 1,800 feet. How the nautilus did this had long been a mystery, but three researchers believe they have solved it.

SANTA FE, N. M. -- Behind the cheerless unity of our national frustration, the hostages in Teheran and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan have shown again how dangerously alien and obscure international affairs remain for most Americans.
TRENTON, Jan. 28--Governor Byrne made public today a state budget of $5.1 billion for 1980-81 that would require increases in rail and bus fares and higher tuition at state colleges and universities.
A POLITICAL poll, based on a sample of 1,200 voters, reports that your favorite candidate has moved up to second place in voter popularity. Is it time to make another contribution?

TOKYO, Jan. 28--The United States Ambassador warned Japan's two leading auto makers today to invest in assembly plants in the United States or risk setting off American protectionist pressures in an election year.

THE scientist who revolutionized the reform of high school science teaching almost 25 years ago charges that the reforms have been killed by the very people who have most to lose from such a course-the scientists themselves.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28--A popular Soviet sports figure acknowledged in Pravda today that "some athletes from America, Canada, Britain and other countries" might not show up at the Olympics next summer because of pressure for a boycott from the United States Government.

Buying demand from institutions and other investors sent the broad price indexes of the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market to record levels yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The Agriculture Department predicted today that exports of American feed grains would total nearly 66 million metric tons during the 1979-80 marketing year ending next October, setting another record despite the loss of more than 10 million tons of corn destined for the Soviet Union before the grain curtailment was imposed.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28-The nation's third largest school system was virtually shut down today when most of its 25,000 teachers stayed away from classes to protest not being paid for almost two weeks.

Robert Fuoss, former editor in chief of The Saturday Evening Post and executive vice president of Federated Department Stores, died Sunday at Natick Hospital in Massachusetts after a brief illness. He was 67 years old and lived in Natick, a suburb of Boston.

Under a Federal formula, New York State must use 8.4 percent less gasoline in the first three months of this year than it did last year, State Energy Commissioner James L. Larocca said yesterday. But the cut is below the 9.5 percent originally set.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--President Carter sent to Congress today proposed legislation that would open 23 million acres of Federal land in northern Alaska to oil and gas exploitation by private companies.
Until last fall, Marion Callister of Boise Idaho, was a high-ranking officer of the Mormon Church, which is working intensely to defeat the Equal Rights Amendment.

BARROW, ALASKA HOT tempers and tension arising from a scientific report that found a high rate of alcoholism in this predominantly Eskimo community have abated somewhat after two days of meetings here at the northernmost point of Alaska.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--Even more than in past years, the budget figures unveiled today by President Carter represent more a hope than a likelihood.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The assets of money market mutual funds grew from $10.9 billion at the end of 1978 to $45.2 billion at the end of 1979, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

Paine Webber Inc., the brokerage firm holding company, said yesterday that it earned a record $7 million in the quarter ended Dec. 31, compared with $564,00 a year ago. Revenues increased 57.3 percent, rising to $168.5 million from $107.1 million in the 1978 quarter. Fourth-quarter figures did not include Blyth Eastman Dillon Company, merged with Paine Webber on Dec. 31.

The 35th American Folksong Festival Concert will be held on Feb. 11 at 8 P.M. in the Great Hall of Cooper Union, Third Avenue and Seventh Street.

The Union Pacific Corporation, the railroad-based holding company that has in recent years expanded into the development of petroleum and natural resources, reported yesterday that its earnings increased 26.6 percent in the fourth quarter and 44.8 percent for the year.

FOR the first time in nearly two years, Bill Walton will compete tonight in a National Basketball Association game. Hank Aaron, major league baseball's home run king, yesterday settled what he considered an old score with Commissioner Bowie Kuhn.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 28 (AP) -- DeWayne Scales scored 21 points as Louisiana State University used a slowdown offense to upset Kentucky, 65-60, in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.

Erratic price swings buffeted the precious metals and copper futures markets yesterday in trading dominated by the expiration of the pivotal spot, or maturing, January contracts.
BASRA, Iraq, Jan. 25--Iranian troops can be seen along the disputed river boundary between Iraq and Iran near here just as they were during the rule of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

A small tribe of nomadic hunters, heretofore unknown, has been found in Papua New Guinea by a group of explor ers with Operation Drake, an aroundthe-world expedition now in its second year out from England.

PHOENIX, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Twentytwo legal documents show that Frank Kush--the football coach at Arizona State University who was removed in a furor that began with charges that he had punched a player--hit, kicked and otherwise punished players when he felt that fear or pain was needed to get top performance, according to an article in The Arizona Republic.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 28 (AP)-- More than 100 steelworkers chanting "we want jobs" crashed through a glass door and occupied the offices of United States Steel Corporation for six hours today to protest the planned closing of two plants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--President Carter sent to Congress today a budget for the fiscal year 1981 that holds the line on most nonmilitary programs, forecasts a mild recession and high unemployment, and omits the usual antirecession, election-year tonic of a tax cut.
To the Congress of the United States: This budget for 1981 is prudent and responsible. It continues the strategy of restraint that I proposed, and the Congress accepted, for the 1980 budget.

THE 10th season of the "Lyrics and Lyricists" series at the 92d Street Y, which is being cele brated by repeat performances by some of the lyricists whose programs stood out during the first nine years, began Sunday evening with E. Y. Harburg.

WASHINGTON--Workers' efforts to promote safety and health on the job have focused on forcing action by employers. In the coming decade, increasing pressure may also be put on the manufacturing firms that design and supply equipment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--John G. Heimann, Comptroller of the Currency, today approved the application of Marine Midland Bank to convert from a state to a national banking charter. John Huston will be honored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center on May 5 for his accomplishments as a director, screenwriter and writer, collaborator and actor during his 51 years in motion pictures.

New York, playing without its all-pro center, Althea Gwyn, who was sidleined with a knee injury, shot 39 percent from the floor and was outrebounded, 53-42. The loss was the Stars' fifth in 23 games and third in the last four games.

The owners of the 21 clubs in the National Hockey League yesterday made the players an offer on free-agent compensation that would be much the same as the system currently in effect in pro football. The player representatives promptly rejected it.

Steel production rose to 2.5 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, up 2.4 percent from the previous week's 2.4 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

HORIZON "The Future of the University" will be discussed by a distinguished sociologist tomorrow at 5 P.M. The public is invited to attend at Milbank Chapel of Teachers College/ Columbia University, 525 West 120th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue. The speaker is Robert Nisbet, professor emeritus of sociology at Columbia.

One syringe contains lethal doses of barbiturates. The other two contain salt water.

DETROIT, March 3 (AP)-- Cadillac, which introduced the V-8 engine to motoring in 1914, announced today that it would offer its first six-cylinder engine beginning April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)--A reinforced battalion of 1,800 marines is en route to the Indian Ocean aboard a fourship Navy amphibious group, the Pentagon said today.

But it's going to come alive-- the whole world's going to come alive at Easter."

George A. Van Epps, a one-time barnstorming pilot in upstate New York who became Eastern Area supervisor for the National Transportation Safety Board at Kennedy International Airport, died of cancer Saturday at Mid-Island Hospital in Bethpage, L.I. He was 67 years old and lived in Levittown, L.I.
WASHINGTON, March 3--The Supreme Court ruled today that a California law that allows wine producers to set the price for their products was invalid under the Sherman Antitrust Act.

THE HAGUE, March 4 (Reuters)-- Strikes disrupted public transportation, ports and industry in most parts of the Netherlands today. The stoppages, some due to last 24 hours, were called by the largest Dutch trade union in protest against the Government's wages policy.

STOCKHOLM, March 4 (Reuters)-- The Nobel prizes this year will be worth $210,000 each, a rise of 10 percent, the Nobel Foundation announced today. The increase is possible as a result of profits from investments, the foundation said. The winners will be named in the fall.

PARIS, March 4--The second of the big three in French restaurant guides, the Guide Kleber, has changed its format to bring it more in line with its two competitors, Guide Michelin and the Gault-Millau Guide to France. The Kleber was released today, a week in advance of Michelin and a month after the 1980 Gault-Millau.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, March 3-- Viktor Kupreichik, a Russian grandmaster, remained in first place with a 5 -1 score after seven rounds of the ninth Reykjavik International Tournament.

ALBANY, March 4--Led by Amyas Ames, chairman of Lincoln Center, more than 200 representatives of cultural groups from across the state piled into buses and descended on legislators here today to press for more financial support for the arts.
BOSTON, March 4--The Kennedys never needed their own more than they did this day, and the ward workers were out early under a sun risen clear as the threat on the ballot.

EASTON, Pa., March 4--James Salters hit an 18-foot jump shot from the right of the lane with 11 seconds to go to give Penn a 50-49 victory over Princeton tonight in their one-game playoff for the Ivy League basketball title. It also gave the Quakers the final berth in the 48-team National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

LONDON, March 4--The British Government hailed the success of the Rhodesian elections today while wondering privately and slightly apprehensively about what lay ahead.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)--The Senate Judiciary Committee rejected by an 9-to-6 vote today President Carter's nomination of Charles H. Winberry of Rocky Mount, N.C., to be a Federal district judge.
Royes Fernandez, a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater for many years, died of cancer Monday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 50 years old.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 4-- Robert Mugabe began forming a black majority government today within hours of his sweeping election victory and immediately assured the 230,000 whites that their fears of property seizures and other retributions for the past were unfounded.

However, a note following the recipe will tell the "hearthless" how to produce this fine bread in the oven.

The nation's three biggest air carriers servicing the New YorkCalifornia route, American Airlines, Trans World Airlines and United Airlines, said yesterday that they were studying the plan by Eastern Air Lines to introduce bargain fares when it enters that highly competitive route on June 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 4 --Following is the text of Resolution 465 on Israeli settlements in occupied territories approved Saturday by the Security Council. The italic paragraph was removed before passage.

Sales of American-made new cars continued downward in the final 10-day selling period of February. The Big Three auto makers reported that collectively their retail sales were 20.3 percent below the sales for the corresponding period a year earlier.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., March 4-- Again most shops are closed by 5:30 P.M., restaurants expect their best dinner crowds at 6 and Main Street is virtually deserted by 9.

The detective, Robert Frank, doubled over with the force of the shot, but it did not penetrate his skin.

KINGSTON, Jamaica--In Jamaica, campaigning has already begun for the general election called by Prime Minister Michael Manley for October. WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)-- New orders received by the nation's factories surged 3.6 percent, to $155.1 billion, in January, the largest monthly increase since October 1978, the Commerce Department reported today.

Zubin Mehta will conduct half of the 32 weeks of subscription concerts by the New York Philharmonic next season, his third as music director. And ticket prices will be raised in some areas of Avery Fisher Hall. These were among the announcements made by the orchestra for 1980-81.

WASHINGTON, March 4--If Gerald R. Ford decides to enter the Republican Presidential competition within the next two weeks, he can still theoretically put together enough delegates for a majority at the Republican National Convention in July.

IN the early 1970's, the Prudential Insurance Company acquired the 400acre Alderney dairy farm in Parsippany and Hanover townships and started to plan what it chooses to call a business "campus." Last year, the first office building was completed, and a second, for Prudential itself, is well into construction and scheduled for occupancy in the fall.

BOSTON, Wednesday, March 5-- Senator Edward M. Kennedy defeated President Carter by a 2-to-1 margin yesterday in the Massachusetts Democratic Presidential primary. In the Republican contest, Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois and George Bush were locked this morning in a close race for first place.

TOKYO, March 4 (AP)--The Nippon Steel Corporation, Japan's largest steelmaker and the customary price leader, said today that it would raise the prices of various steel products by an average 10.5 percent, or $36 a ton, effective with April shipments.

Canada said yesterday that its official monetary reserves rose by $401.3 million (United States funds) in February, reflecting gold sales and the Canadian dollar's strength. The Finance Department said 107,000 ounces of gold were sold last month, reducing holdings to 21.82 million ounces.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI)--In one of the biggest consumer refunds ever negotiated, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation has agreed to pay $2 million to thousands of buyers whose cars and trucks were repossessed, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

"The Days Grow Short," by Ronald Sanders, which its publishers say is the "first full biography" of Kurt Weill, the composer, will be published May 15 by Holt, Rinehart Winston.

WASHINGTON, March 5--"I don't like to do it, but it's clear that my campaign is not going anywhere," Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee said today as he withdrew from the race for the Republican Presidential nomination he entered 126 days ago. He became the first acknowledged casualty of the early primaries and caucuses.

Parnell in his abduction.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 5--A New York Times article about a large fine that would be imposed against any baseball club official who publicly discussed labor negotiations has led to an investigation by the security men in Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's office. ALBANY, March 6--Howard L. Hurwitz, a retired Queens high school principal with a reputation as a strict disciplinarian, was one of six finalists announced today by the State Legislature to fill two vacancies on the State Board of Regents. There are at-large and Long Island seats vacant.

Chopin, former chairman of the New York Shipping Association and the shipping industry's chief labor negotiator during New York Harbor's busy 1950's and turbulent 1960's, died of a heart attack Wednesday while playing squash at the Nassau Country Club in Glen Cove, L.I. THE last "Don Giovanni" at the New York City Opera was not greeted very enthusiastically. Last night the company tried again, with a new production directed by John Cox that had sets and costumes by Michael Annals (it was his New York City Opera debut). Julius Rudel was the conductor.

WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., March 6 --Pennsylvania has a new Quaker mascot this season. Two of the starters on its basketball team were high school seniors when Penn won the East Regional championship a year ago.

The Mobil Corporation and Texaco Inc. said yesterday that they had given up on court efforts begun last December to block the already completed $3.65 billion merger of the Belridge Oil Company into the Shell Oil Company.

The trustees of Teachers College of Columbia University elected Barbara Furrer Goodman their chairman yesterday. She succeeds William Parsons, a lawyer, who had been chairman since 1962.
Gerel Rubien, an educator and an early women's activist in the trade union movement, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 79 years old.

EAST BERLIN, March 7 (Reuters) A West German woman was sentenced to five years in prison by an East Berlin court today on charges of helping East Germans escape to the West. The official East German press agency identified her as Petra Brandl.

CHICAGO, March 7 (UPI) The executive board of the firefighters' union unanimously approved a tentative agreement tonight to end a 23-day-old strike. A union membership meeting was called for midnight to vote on ratification of the proposed contract.

WASHINGTON, March 7 A stiff Congressional warning went out to Japan today to cut back voluntarily on automobile exports to the United States or face protectionist quota legislation that would damage the trading interests of both countries.
Governor Byrne said last night that he would "look into" an allegation against Richard J. Coffee, the Democratic state chairman.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 7 John B. Connally, who has heavily staked his Presidential hopes on a strong showing in tomorrow's Republican primary election in South Carolina, predicted victory in an exuberant moment today. But most other politicians rated Ronald Reagan the solid favorite in the South's first Presidential contest of 1980.

The Army private played by Zane Lasky in John Heuer's "Innocent Thoughts, Harmless Intentions" (at the Circle Repertory Company) is a loner who desperately wants to be accepted by his peers, but goes about it exactly the wrong way.
The New York City Department of Health yesterday released the names of 29 food-handling establishments that it said had been cited for violations of the health code.

A special telephone hotline has been established that allows Staten Island residents to telephone the New York City Transit Authority's travel information bureau in Brooklyn for a single message unit. The new number is (212) 979-0600. The bureau provides information on bus, subway and ferry schedules.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, March 7 (Reuters) Former President Richard M. Nixon arrived in the Ivory Coast tonight to attend a golf tournament as a guest of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny. The tournament is taking place at Mr. Houphouet-Boigny's hometown of Yamoussoukro, 150 miles north of here.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 As Charles B. Renfrew tells it, his public career came to him uninvited.
Isadore Raff, a founder and chairman of the Washington Federal Savings and Loan Association, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old.
NEW DELHI, March 7 Jagjivan Ram, a prominent leader of the Janata Party and its nominee for prime minister in January, resigned today, forcing a split in the party.

BUENOS AIRES, March 7 (AP) Argentina took a surprising 1-0 lead over the United States in the Davis Cup American Zone final today when Guillermo Vilas defeated Brian Gottfried, 7-5, 6-4, 6-3; Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina led John McEnroe in a match suspended by darkness.

PISCATAWAY, N.J., March 7 The National Basketball Association resurrected an American Basketball Association gimmick this season, hoping to add a little excitement to its game, which had gone a bit stale over the years. The gimmick was the 3-point field goal.

WASHINGTON, March 7 The Government reported today that inflation, as measured by the Producer Price Index, continued to soar at a near-record level in February, increasing the political and economic pressure on the Carter Administration to take action.

WHITE PLAINS, March 7 The nuclear power reactor at Indian Point in Buchanan operated by the Power Authority of the State of New York was shut down today for a week after the second malfunction in four days. A five-month closure for refueling, maintenance and repairs ended two weeks ago.

James C. Shannon, who served briefly as Governor of Connecticut and then as an associate justice of the State Supreme Court from 1953 until his retirement in 1966, died Thursday at the Carolton Hospital in Fairfield, Conn., a convalescent home where he had lived for several years. Mr. Shannon, who had earlier lived in Bridgeport, was 83 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) Roger S. Young, an 18-year veteran of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was named today to head the public affairs office at F.B.I. headquarters.

HONOLULU, March 7 (AP) The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service has stripped residents of the Northern Marianas Islands of their two-year-old status as United States citizens, the agency's district director confirmed here today.

The city's chief labor negotiator, Bruce McIver, told the coalition of uniformed services yesterday that its contract demands, if granted, would cost $650 million over two years and that the city could not afford a settlement of that size.

MARRAKESH, Morocco, March 6 King Hassan II has made it clear that his vision of a negotiated settlement of the four-year war in the Western Sahara is different from solutions outlined by highranking Carter Administration officials and that Morocco will not abandon any territory in the phosphate-rich former Spanish colony.
The nation's major banks increased their prime lending rates yesterday to a record 17 percent from 17 percent. It was the second time this week that the rate went up half a percentage point.

David Schiff's opera "Gimpel the Fool," which had its premiere last season, returned to the stage of the 92d Street Y on Thursday night in a slightly revised form and with two major changes in cast. It was again presented as part of the series called Jewish Opera at the Y.
The credit markets rebounded yesterday afternoon, recovering from an early setback caused by more evidence of rampant inflation and still no definite word from Washington of a program to combat it.

TEL AVIV, March 7 Israel this week inducted a Chief Justice in Jerusalem at a time when the Supreme Court is becoming increasingly involved in strongly contested issues, including Jewish settlement of occupied Arab land.
COLUMBIA, S.C., March 7 If it settles nothing else, the South Carolina Presidential primary is demonstrating that the gritty underside of American politics has not disappeared.

The Grand Union Company and Fisher Foods Inc. yesterday followed the lead of three other major supermarket chains and imposed a 30-day price freeze on some private-label brands in response to a Carter Administration plea to fight rising food costs.

KABUL, Afghanistan, March 7 Wary Soviet soldiers reappeared on the streets of Kabul today and Soviet fighter jets and helicopter gunships buzzed the city as opponents of the Soviet-supported regime of President Babrak Karmal gave indications that they were preparing for a fresh round of strikes and shop closings next week.
MERCED, Calif., March 7 (UPI) Five-year-old Timmy White became a crucial witness today in the case against a drifter who allegedly abducted him and another youth as his "sons."

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) Imports of color television sets were cut in half in 1979 under special marketing agreements between the United States and Japan, Taiwan and Korea, the Government reported today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Saturday, March 8 The Iranian Government announced last night that Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh would go to the occupied United States Embassy today and take charge of both the hostages and the embassy compound.

PROVIDENCE, March 7 Despite a chipped bone in his left hand and a badly bruised right hand, Jeff Ruland played 39 minutes, scored 16 points and helped Iona extend its winning streak to 17 games tonight with an 84-78 victory over Holy Cross in a first-round game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

They want to be priests and rabbis; they want to hold high office in the religious hierarchy; they want to pray in a liturgy free of masculine imagery and vocabulary. The marriage of Melissa Lewis, daughter of Joseph A. Lewis of Atlanta and Anilee G. Lewis of Charlotte, N.C., to David W. Bernstein, son of Dr. Sidney A. Bernstein of New York and the late Mrs. Bernstein, took place yesterday afternoon.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. March 7 To the New York Mets, third base is Moby Dick. For 18 years, they have been consumed in a relentless search for the one player who might capture the position and end the team's most haunting obsession.

A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with committing 17 bank robberies 16 in Manhattan and one in Brooklyn since Dec. 31. The last occurred Thursday, when $150 was taken from a Chase Manhattan Bank branch at Madison Avenue and 57th Street, the police said.
CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) A judge ruled today that John W. Gacy Jr. was mentally fit to stand trial on murder charges stemming from the sex killings of 33 young men and boys.

CHICAGO, March 7 (UPI) The Chicago Tribune and The Chicago Sun-Times will endorse Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois for the Republican nomination for President, the newspapers said today. The endorsements, to appear Sunday, follow Mr. Anderson's near upsets Tuesday of George Bush in Massachusetts and Ronald Reagan in Vermont.
MEXICO CITY, March 7 El Salvador's army-backed junta today followed up its expropriation of large private farms 24 hours earlier by announcing the nationalization of the country's banking system.

ALBANY, March 7 (UPI) There will be almost 275,000 fewer Republicans and Democrats eligible to vote in this month's New York Presidential primary than in the primary last Sept. 11, the state's Board of Elections said today.

The first class of recruits appointed to the Police Department in five years 410 student officers received badges at a ceremony at the Police Academy yesterday. Also receiving their badges were 29 recruits of the Housing Authority police, who are getting their training at the academy.

NOCERA INFERIORE, Italy, March 7 (AP) Five bandits stopped an express train today by forcing a switchman to flash a red signal, but the gang picked the wrong car and made off with only four pouches of letters. Officials said cash and other valuables were being transported in another mail car.

PEKING, March 7 Not long ago an American resident of Peking invited a Chinese friend to dinner in a restaurant. To save trouble on the telephone, the Chinese volunteered to book a table in his name.

WASHINGTON, March 7 The Labor Department reported today that the national unemployment rate edged down to 6 percent in February from 6.2 percent in January and that the number of persons with jobs showed a small rise.

Anna Duncan, the dancer who was one of Isadora Duncan's original pupils and adopted daughters, died in Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx yesterday. She had been blind and chronically ill for some time. She was 85 years old and had lived at the Home for the Aged Blind in Yonkers since 1977.

ALBANY, March 7 Six days out of Costa Rica, the Condata steamed up the Hudson River 143 miles to Albany, one of the nation's leading inland seaports, carrying bananas to be eaten from New York City to Montreal and Boston to Buffalo.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 7 The foreign ministers of the European Common Market and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations today jointly condemned the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 7 After five years of apparently frustrating negotiations with several multinational companies, Saudi Arabia is pressing to reach agreement on proposals to build five giant petrochemical plants in joint ventures with these companies.
Depressing economic news sent the stock market broadly lower yesterday in accelerated trading, with the oil and precious-metal issues the biggest losers for the second consecutive session.

Mayor Koch's administration has asked the city's Investigation Commissioner to study the involvement of the president of a New York City bus-shelter company in a proposed $12.5 million hotel complex in Brooklyn.
MONTREAL, March 7 (AP) Clarence Campbell, a former National Hockey League president, was sentenced to a token one day in jail and fined $25,000 today for conspiracy to bribe a Canadian senator.

FORT MONROE, Va., March 7 (AP) The Army said yesterday that it had dismissed charges that Brig. Gen. F. Cecil Adams Jr. condoned cheating in recruiting programs to meet quotas. The dismissal came after an inquiry found there was no evidence to support the charges, according to Lieut. Col. W.G. Smith of the Training and Doctrine Command. The charges were filed by Sgt. Lillie B. Clay, who faces recruiting fraud charges.

Six films featuring Irene Dunne, the versatile dramatic and light-comedy actress of the 30's, will be shown at the Thalia Theater on West 95th Street, just off Broadway, in a three-day series starting March 11.

WASHINGTON Sovietologists have been reminding us that the Soviet Union faces an energy crunch. The invasion of Afghanistan struck in the midst of instability in the entire oilproducing Persian Gulf region.

BOSTON, March 7 (Reuters) American Airlines Inc. said today that it had asked for authority to provide one daily Boeing 747 round-trip flight between Boston and London starting immediately. The Civil Aeronautics Board this week started a proceeding to determine which airline should be selected for the route under a new bilateral agreement between the United States and Britain.

TOKYO, March 7 (UPI) Kuwait is asking for a $10 surcharge on its Government-to-Government oil sales to Japan, industry sources said today. The direct-deal price had been $27.50 a barrel. Japanese oil refiners and trading houses termed the demand outrageous and suspended negotiations for long-term imports with the Kuwait State Oil Company, the sources said. The two countries had been negotiating the price of long-term shipment since mid-February.
WASHINGTON, March 7 The MCI Telecommunications Corporation has started its first long-distance telephone service for residential users.

STERLING, Conn., March 4 There was the flood of 1928, memorialized in photographs in the town's bicentennial edition of its history, and some old-timers recall the hurricane of 1938 and the forest fire of 1942. But the fire that swept through the Revere Textile Print Mill's 16 buildings last Saturday was far more traumatic for this town.
Irving Siegel, retired principal of Charles Evans Hughes High School in lower Manhattan, died Wednesday at Cabrini Hospital. He lived in Peter Cooper Village and was 61 years old.

Despite encouraging notices from American observers, last fall's unseasonable "Seoul Spring" had a disappointingly short run. Recent reports, though, suggest a genuine political thaw may be imminent in South Korea.

When Paul A. Volcker became chairman of the Federal Reserve Board last August, the move was almost universally applauded. The consensus was that Mr. Volcker had the commitment and the expertise to impose the tightmoney policies needed to reduce inflation.
Gold traded below the $600-an-ounce mark yesterday as rising interest rates increased the cost of holding the precious metal and lifted the value of the dollar on currency exchanges.

SAN ANTONIO, March 7 The struggling San Antonio Spurs postponed a session scheduled for this afternoon with a hypnotist, but they started tonight's game as if playing in a trance and dropped a 118-112 decision to the New York Knicks.

Allegations of illegal sales of cooperative apartments for large profits by residents on Roosevelt Island are being investigated by the New York State Attorney General's office and the state housing agency. The profits, said to be as high as $25,000, would be illegal because the maximum resale prices are fixed by the state, which financed the $150 million complex.

Dennis Cleary is a feisty, 40-year-old individual whose schooling ended when he was graduated from a Brooklyn high school. He held a variety of jobs, hauled trash for the city's Department of Sanitation and worked his way up to a job as foreman in the coordinator's office.

The producers of the forthcoming revival of "My Fair Lady" have won their battle to cast a British actress as Eliza Doolittle. She is Cheryl Kennedy, who, an arbitrator found, "would provide unique services" for "My Fair Lady." The musical, which will star Rex Harrison as Professor Higgins, the role he created in 1956, will go into rehearsal in August for a nationwide tour.

SAN FRANCISCO At Jerry Lewis's self-help garage here, it's the women who wear the coveralls. In fact, half of the 150 members and all three of the full-time mechanics at this semicommercial, semicooperative repair shop are women. And automobile repairs at the garage cost far less than they would elsewhere in the area.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 7 Declaring that "living with and working with our enemies has never been a problem," former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith today declared his availability to serve in the Cabinet of Robert Mugabe, the man whose guerrilla forces forced Mr. Smith to abandon his bid to uphold white minority rule.
WASHINGTON, March 7 The Uniroyal Tire Company is calling in two million of its 1975-77 steel-belted radials because the Government says they might be dangerous.

CULVER CITY, Calif., March 6 "Being There" captured two Academy Award nominations this month. "Cruising" touched off protests by homosexual groups during its filming and later led to an industrywide debate over the merits of the rating system.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. The United States Supreme Court's 5-4 decision in the Yeshiva University case sounded the death knell for faculty unions in private colleges and universities in the United States. In addition, there will be a carry-over impact in the public sector, where there are 302 unions representing approximately 122,000 faculty members.
American journalists have been readmitted to Iran and began filing news reports to the United States early yesterday for the first time since Jan. 14.

The Peoples Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to aquire the Exeter Company for about $74 million in Peoples common stock and $64 million in cash and notes. The transaction is subject to approval by stockholders.

The Rev. William C. Bier, a Jesuit who was one of the founders of the American Catholic Psychological Association and a professor of psychology and administrator at Fordham University for 32 years, died of a heart attack Thursday at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 68 years old.

PEKING, March 7 China has appointed a veteran bureaucrat to the important job of director of the Communist Party's propaganda department, intensifying concern among some intellectuals that the recent period of greater freedom of expression may be over.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 7 Syrian troops pulled out of the Christian suburbs of Beirut today and were redeploying in the Bekaa Valley in eastern Lebanon.

The basic measure of the money supply declined by $2.8 billion in the week ended Feb. 27, while, in the same period, business loans at the nation's large banks declined by $458 million, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON A PATENT was granted this week on a target-seeking gyro, also known as the Sidewinder mis sile, which has been widely used by American and allied military forces. The missile was invented in 1947 by the late William B. McLean, then director of the Naval Ordnance Test Station at China Lake, Calif., and was kept secret for a quarter-century.

WASHINGTON, March 7 Senator Edward M. Kennedy hopes that the Republicans will nominate George Bush or former President Gerald R. Ford and thus put pressure on the Democratic convention to choose him over President Carter, his deputy campaign manager said today.

Broadway is currently casting the Portman Hotel as the bad guy in a municipal melodrama of greed and destruction. The title is, "How the Helen Hayes, Morosco and Bijou Theaters Were Lost to Rapacious Real Estate; or, Portman, Go Home." It is particularly sad to see this script playing so well to the acting profession, which has a large stake in the survival and therefore revival of the Times Square theater district.

Mayor Koch, fresh from his trip to China and Japan, warned yesterday that his continued support of the Westway project depended on Governor Carey's making good his promise to maintain the 50-cent transit fare in New York City.

The Spanish National Television Network has recruited such Hispanic celebrities as Jose Ferrer, Rita Moreno and Erik Estrada to appear on special programs to encourage cooperation with the 1980 Census and explain its function.

WASHINGTON, March 7 Fifty members of District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees sat down in their New York City headquarters 18 months ago to talk about their lives and their jobs.

Diane Frank and Deborah Riley collaborated to choreograph "Brace," the new work they offered Thursday night at the American Theater Laboratory. Together, they created a fascinating dance consisting of endless curlicues of movement.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 7 The third negotiating session between the Colombian Government and a representative of the guerrillas holding an international group of diplomats hostage in the Dominican Republic Embassy took place this afternoon with no indication that a settlement was near.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 7 If a ballerina wanted to improve her dancing, she could seek advice from Cynthia Gregory. If a musician wanted to become a better violinist, he could go to Pinchas Zukerman. These days Reggie Jackson listens to Paul Blair.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) Sales of existing houses across the country continued to slump in January as record interest rates drove buyers out of the market, the National Association of Realtors said today.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) The nation's top-ranking judges today attacked a proposed "sunshine law" that would require them to go public when meeting to discuss court administration.

The decision by most major banks yesterday to increase their prime lending rate to 17 percent left many futures markets with sharply lower prices because investors and hedgers were reluctant to buy forward contracts that have built-in interest, insurance and storage charges.

MIAMI, March 5 In a small factory where the air tastes like cotton candy, Jeb Bush shouted a steady stream of Spanish-language campaign talk above the clatter of machines that make half the nation's daily supply of Sweet 'n' Low, the sweetener. But Mr. Bush repeatedly punctuated his fluent Spanish with one English expression: the initials C.I.A.

The State Public Service Commission yesterday authorized a rate increase of 8 percent, or $28.8 million a year, for the Consolidated Edison Company's more than one million gas customers in New York City and Westchester County. They now pay $360 million a year for gas.

The nation's traffic deaths exceeded 50,000 for the second year in a row in 1979 after a four-year decline following the 1973 gasoline shortage, according to recently compiled statistics. Some highway safety experts attribute the increasing fatalities to the growing number of smaller cars.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 7 (AP) A White House study group report is urging the Government, for the first time, to accept responsibility for cancer among some people living downwind from nuclear weapons test sites in Nevada, a Utah newspaper says.

WASHINGTON, March 17 President Carter signed into law today a bill that would increase the number of refugees admitted regularly to the United States each year to 50,000 from 17,500, according to Administration officials.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 17 A year ago a financially strapped would-be politician from Taiwan traveled from Japan into China to arrange an illicit business deal that he hoped would net him a quick fortune.

The General Tire Rubber Company announced yesterday that it had filed a proposal with the Federal Communications Commission to sell its Boston television station and spin off a new corporation from its broadcasting subusidiary, RKO General Inc.

SAN LUCAS, Mexico The modernday United States colonizers businesses and tourists are succeeding where 19th-century, politicians and soldiers failed: They are slowly taking over Mexico's "last frontier," the desolate peninsula of mountains and desert that is Lower California.
